DIRECTIONS FOR USE
Look for the year you want in the inder al lent. The number opposite each year is the number of the calendar to use for that year.

ARPANET DIRECTORY INTRODUCTION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
BRIEF EXPLANATION OF THIS DIRECTORY
ATTENTION
The ARPANET Directory is the property of the Department of Defense. It is to be used solely for the conduct of, or in support of, official U.S. government business.
Its use for advertising, mail distribution lists , or for any other unauthorized purpose is strictly prohibited . Any individuals or hosts who violate this prohibition will have their listings deleted from both this directory and the online system directory.
NIC INFORMATION
Services and documents available from the Network Information Center ( NIC)
are described in this section of the Directory.
ARPANET INFORMATION
General information , useful definitions, policies, and procedures for using the
ARPANET are included in this section.
CONTACTS
Lists general network contacts, as well as the ARPANET Sponsors and the
ARPANET Liaison.
INDIVIDUALS
Individuals who are authorized ARPANET users and who have supplied the proper information to the ARPANET Network Information Center are listed
alphabetically by last name in the INDIVIDUALS section of the directory. The
format is :
INDIVIDUAL'S NAME NIC IDENT
HARDCOPY - MAIL - ADDRESS
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS
PHONE NUMBER
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT
where
NIC IDENT = a unique code ( usually one's initials) by which the NIC Identification System recognizes and locates an individual .
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS is in the form : USER - NAME@ HOST - NAME.
The HOST NAME portion identifies a computer ( host) attached to the
ARPANET at which the individual receives delivery of his network mail. The
USER NAME portion of the network mail address is the character sequence by which that host identifies the user's incoming mail.
NOTE: The statement 'Network Address Unknown' indicates that no
network mail address was received by the NIC from the individual in
question .
1
INTRODUCTION
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT = the official identification code for
the host with which an individual is associated; or if no ARPANET host
exists, an identification code representing the organization with which the
individual is associated .
NETWORK MAILBOX INDEX
This table is organized alphabetically by network mailbox along with the corresponding individual's name. It is a subset of the INDIVIDUALS listing and indicates what individuals are associated with which mailboxes.
HOSTS AND ASSOCIATES
Hosts are computers connected to the ARPANET. There are three kinds of
hosts: SERVERS, USERs and TIPS. SERVERS have implemented SERVER
TELNET and are capable of providing services to remote users across the
network. USERs let individuals access resources elsewhere on the network, but
do not provide services of their own and have not implemented SERVER
TELNET. TIPs are interface message processors with terminal connections.
They function as special - case users. Associates are network - related organizations that do not have hosts connected to the ARPANET. Hosts and
associates are listed alphabetically by organization name in the format:
ORGANIZATION NAME OFFICIAL HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
and by host acronym in the format:
HOST NAME HOST ADDR STATUS SPONSOR NAME OF LIAISON
ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
LIAISON'S PHONE NO.
or by associate acronym in the format:
ASSOCIATE IDENT ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
where
OFFICIAL HOST NAME = a unique acronym, obtained through negotiation with the NIC, by which a host is known on the ARPANET.
ASSOCIATE IDENT = an identification acronym for associate organizations,
assigned by the NIC or the sponsoring organization.
HOST NUMBER/IMP NUMBER ASSIGNMENTS
The Host No./IMP No. Table specifies which hosts are attached to each IMP or
TIP.
COMPUTERS
The Computer Tables list network hosts organized by computer configuration
and by computer manufacturer.
2
ARPANET DIRECTORY NIC INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER SERVICES
WHAT THE NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER (NIC) DOES
The NIC serves as a center for collection and dissemination of information
about the ARPANET. It is located at SRI International in Menlo Park, California.
The NIC was begun in 1970 as a research project to develop a prototypical network information center, and up until July 1 , 1975 was sponsored by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency ( DARPA) . Currently it is funded
by the Defense Communications Agency (DCA) to provide the services outlined
below .
PUBLICATIONS
The Network Information Center publishes the following documents:
The ARPANET Directory A directory of users and hosts on the ARPANET. It gives the names, online and offline mail addresses, phone number, and host affiliation of ARPANET users, as well as summary tables of host information.
The ARPANET Protocol Handbook - A collection of the currently accepted network protocols.
The ARPANET Resource Handbook - a compendium of the resources available
on the ARPANET.
NICNOTES Informal newsnotes distributed online by the NIC to the Liaison
and other interested people. NICNOTES are primarily concerned with
announcement of changes of hostnames and host addresses on the ARPANET.
ONLINE REFERENCE FILES
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET HOSTNAMES LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 66 dec) as
<NETINFO>HOSTS.TXT
This file contains the official list of hostnames and host addresses for hosts
attached to the ARPANET. It consists of hostname, host address, type of
host (i.e. , USER, SERVER, or TIP) and host nickname, if any. It is accessible
to any network user for reference, and is mainly used to update local hostname recognition tables. The reference file meets criteria outlined in
RFC 608.
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET LIAISON LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 66 dec) as <NETINFO>LIAISON.TXT
This file contains name, U. S. mail address, network mail address, phone,
and host affiliation for each network Liaison.
3
NIC INFORMATION
THE LIAISON NETWORK MAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL (66 dec) as
< NETINFO > LIAISON - SNDMSG.TXT
This file contains network mail addresses for all Network Liaison formatted
for online group distribution of messages via SNDMSG.
REQUEST FOR COMMENTS ( RFCS)
Current Network Working Group (NWG) papers, known as RFCs, are kept online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL (66 dec) . These are
maintained by the Coordinator of the NWG, currently Jon Postel, and are
announced via an online distribution list . Each RFC remains online for at
least 21 days to give users a chance to obtain copies. Individuals wishing to be added to the RFC notification list should contact Jon Postel
(POSTEL @ ISIB ).
NIC/QUERY
Most of the information contained in the Resource Handbook is maintained
online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL. This information may be
viewed through the NIC/QUERY program . The query program is geared
toward novice or casual users and is available to all . (See ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES below. )
ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES
Connect to SRI - KL ( 66 dec) and type:
[ @] nic <CR>
where
@ the SRI - KL TENEX herald
<CR> = a carriage return typed by the user
then follow the instructions that are printed out.
NOTE: Users may use this account for viewing reference files in the
NIC / Query system, but they may not use it to access other programs. It cannot be used for linking or loading the FTP program.
HARDCOPY DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION
The NIC maintains files of many hardcopy documents pertaining to the
ARPANET. Although the NIC ( since 9/74) does not officially distribute
hardcopy documents to network users, it will attempt to honor Interlibrary Loan
requests for items in the NIC collection that are not available in the open
literature. This service is provided to the extent that funds and staff permit and is not guaranteed.
4
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
ARPANET GENERAL INFORMATION
USEFUL DEFINITIONS
INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR ( IMP)
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to four host
computers. The original IMPs and TIPs were Honeywell 316 and 516 machines. NOTE: There will not be any additional 316 or 516 IMPs
added to the network as Honeywell has stopped manufacturing them.
TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR ( TIP )
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to three host
computers and 63 terminals. Each terminal may be either asynchronous or externally clocked , and may operate at speeds up to 2400 baud on input
and 19.2 kilobaud on output. Some types of intelligent terminals are also
supported.
PLURIBUS INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which can accomodate in excess of 18 host computers, depending upon configuration. This type IMP has higher throughput capacity and can be
configured redundantly for improved reliability.
PLURIBUS TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR ( PTIP)
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which
can accomodate in excess of 12 hosts simultaneously with several hundred
terminals. Other characteristics are similar to the Honeywell TIPs.
HOST
A customer - owned computer which is connected to a host port on an IMP or TIP. Hosts may be categorized in two ways:
-
DISTANT Host A host which is more than 30 feet, but less than
2,000 feet, from an IMP or TIP.
LOCAL Host A host located within 30 feet of an IMP or TIP.
VERY DISTANT Host A host which is located over 2,000 feet from an
IMP or TIP and requires modems on its access line.
or
SERVER Host - A host that has implemented SERVER TELNET and is capable of providing computer access to distant users via the network.
USER Host - A host that is not capable of providing computer access
across the network, but whose members may use the network to access SERVER Hosts. NOTE: The port taken up by the terminal access on a
TIP is considered a special case User, although technically no computer is attached to the TIP port.
5
ARPANET INFORMATION
TERMINAL
A teletypewriter, CRT, or similar unit which is connected to a terminal port
of a TIP.
INTERSWITCH TRUNKS
A circuit between packet switches (e.g. , IMPs and TIPs) which is used to
pass packets through the network .
ACCESS LINE
A circuit from a host computer or terminal to an IMP or TIP. The circuit
may be a local cable or a transmission facility requiring modems.
ARPANET BACKBONE
The switching nodes (e.g., IMPs and TIPs) , interfaces, the communication
lines interconnecting the nodes, and the Network Control Center ( NCC) .
The backbone is also known as the communications subnet.
SPONSOR
A MILDEP, DOD Agency, or other U. S. Government Agency which is
responsible for an ARPANET user( s) and reimburses DCA for the ARPANET
backbone costs. The Agency is authorized to sponsor a contractor or other nongovernment activity for access to the ARPANET for the purpose of
conducting official U. S. Government business. (See CONTACTS, ARPANET
Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. )
NODE
The packet switch ; an IMP/TIP or Pluribus IMP/TIP.
WHAT THE ARPANET IS
The ARPANET is an operational, resource sharing, host - to - host network linking a wide variety of computers at research centers sponsored by Defense
Advanced Research Projects Agency ( DARPA) and other DoD and non - DoD activities in continental United States, Hawaii, Norway, and England.
The ARPANET orginated as a purely experimental network in late 1969 under
a research and development program sponsored by DARPA to advance the state - of - the - art in computer internetting. The network was designed to
provide efficient communications between heterogeneous computers so that hardware, software, and data resources could be conveniently and economically shared by a wide community of users . As the network successfully attained its
initial design goals, additional users were authorized access to the network.
Today, the ARPANET provides support for a large number of DoD and non - DoD government projects with an operational network of many nodes and host
computers.
Following the successful accomplishment of initial ARPANET design goals and the expansion of the network, it was considered appropriate to transfer the responsibility for operation of the ARPANET from DARPA to the Defense
Communications Agency ( DCA) . In July 1975, the DCA became the operational
manager of the ARPANET.
6
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE ARPANET
The ARPANET is an operational, computerized, packet switching DoD digital network which provides a capability for terminals or geographically separated
computers, called hosts, to communicate with each other. The host computers often differ from one another in type, speed, word length , operating system ,
and other characteristics. Each terminal or host computer is connected into
the network through a small local node computer called an IMP or TIP. The
complete network is formed by interconnecting the IMPs through wideband
communication lines ( normally 50,000 bits per second) supplied by common
carriers.
Each node is programmed to receive and forward messages to the neighboring nodes in the network . During a typical operation, a host passes a message to
its node; the message is passed from node to node through the network until
it finally arrives at the destination IMP, which in turn passes it along to the
destination host. This process normally takes less than 250 milliseconds.
Hosts communicate with each other via regular messages. A regular message
may vary in length from 96 to 8159 bits, the first 96 of which are control
bits called the leader. The leader is also used for sending control messages
between the host and its IMP or TIP ( node) . The remainder of the message is
the data or text.
For each regular message, the host specifies a destination, consisting of node,
host, and handling type. These three parameters uniquely specify a connection between source and destination hosts. The handling type gives the connection
specific characteristics, such as priority or non - priority transmission. Additional leader space has been reserved for a fourth parameter, to be used in future internetwork addressing. For each connection, messages are delivered to the
destination in the same order that they were transmitted by the source.
For each regular message, the host also specifies a 12 - bit identifier, the
message - ID. The message -ID, together with the destination of the message, is
used as the " name " of the message. The node uses this name to inform the
host of the disposition of the message. Therefore, if the host refrains from
re - using a particular message - ID value (to a given destination) until the node has responded about that message -ID, messages will remain uniquely identified
and the host can retransmit them in the event of a failure within the network.
After receiving a regular message from a host connected to it , a node breaks
the message into several packets (currently the maximum data bits per packet
is 1008) and passes these through the network in the direction of the
destination. Eventually, when all packets arrive at the destination , they are reassembled to form the original message which is passed to the destination
host. The destination node returns a positive acknowledgment for receipt of the message to the source host. This acknowledgment is called a Ready for Next Message ( RFNM) and identifies the message being acknowledged by
name. In some relatively rare cases, however, the message may not be
delivered due to a node failure; line disruption, etc. , in such cases an
Incomplete Transmission message will be returned to the source host instead of a RFNM. In this case the message which was incompletely trnasmitted is also
identified by name.
7
ARPANET INFORMATION
If a response from the destination node (either RFNM or Incomplete
Transmission ) is not delivered to the originating host, this condition will be detected by the source node, which will automatically inquire of the destination
node whether the original message was correctly received and repeat the inquiry until a response is received from the destination node. This inquiry
mechanism is timeout - driven , and each timeout period may vary between 30 and 45 seconds in length .
When a message arrives at its destination node, the leader is modified to
indicate the source host, but the message - ID field is passed through unchanged . Thus, in addition to providing message identification between a
host and its local node, the message - ID can provide a means for hosts to identify messages between themselves.
Users of the ARPANET may access local or distant SERVER computers ( hosts)
over the network. They may also exchange messages, create realtime links
between users, transfer files from one computer to another, and submit batch jobs to distant computers. For a more complete description of these processes,
see the ARPANET Protocol Handbook available from the NIC or the National
Technical Information System (NTIS) , Springfield, Va. 22161 as AD A052594.
MANAGEMENT OF THE ARPANET
The Director, DCA controls system engineering and exercises operational
direction over those operating elements of ARPANET which are part of the backbone. ARPANET user equipment and terminals are non - backbone.
ARPANET users must be responsive to management instructions issued by the DCA regarding the ARPANET.
The Director, DCA, will monitor the effectiveness of the ARPANET on a
continuing basis, evaluate those matters which have major impact or will impact
adversely on the network, and direct action to alleviate or prevent such impact.
ARPANET responsibilities of DCA are
. To set policies, procedures, and standards for the operation and
maintenance of the ARPANET.
To approve new user access
. To lease the backbone and terminal access circuits
To maintain the backbone hardware
. To approve changes in the network
To set access criteria
To plan, program , and budget for the resources
. To protect government assets
To provide configuration control
. To coordinate activities impacting the network
. To act as Chairman of the Network Sponsors Group
8
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
. To evaluate the performance of the network
. To carry out topology studies
· To support the Network Information Center (NIC)
. To collect performance statistics
ARPANET POLICIES
ARPANET policies are outlined in the ARPANET Information Brochure available
from the ARPANET Management Branch, Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305
or from NTIS as AD A052672.
ARPANET SOFTWARE MODIFICATIONS
There are two general procedures for software modifications: 1 ) patches to correct deficiencies (bugs ) in the operating program , 2) changes which are
identified and approved for implementation. The software for the IMPs and
TIPs is programmed in assembly language for maximum operating efficiency and use of available software. Software changes are tested and debugged at
BBN prior to release. The software change releases are scheduled for testing and implementation on Tuesdays between 0700 and 0900 Boston time.
To insure that users are fully aware of major software changes which may
affect their operations, changes will be processed in the following manner:
. A specification will be developed for each approved program change proposal.
For those program changes viewed as having potential impact
on the users, the specifications will be coordinated with the
user prior to coding.
Subsequently, a Software Release Notice (SRN) will be
distributed to all users as far in advance as possible but not
less than 30 days prior to implementation (emergency changes
excepted ). The SRN will provide the data required to users to
adjust to the system change being implemented.
THE NETWORK CONTROL CENTER ( NCC)
The Network Control Center ( NCC) for the ARPANET is primarily concerned with the reliability of the network, particularly the detection of line failures and IMP
or TIP failures. In addition, the NCC monitors volumes of host traffic and line
traffic which can give advance warning of network elements whose capacity may need to be increased and which can also be used for site usage
accounting. The NCC maintains other data, such as sense switches, auto restart, memory protect settings, etc. , and buffer usage for each IMP/ TIP. This
data is helpful in diagnosing IMP/TIP failures. Due to the constant monitoring
of the ARPANET at the NCC, the operational availability of the network is very high (consistently in excess of 99 %) .
The NCC is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts and is operated by Bolt,
Beranek , and Newman, Inc. under contract to the Defense Communications
Agency. (See also CONTACTS section. )
9
ARPANET INFORMATION
THE ARPANET SPONSORS GROUP
The ARPANET Sponsors Group is made up of representatives from the various
DoD or U. S. Government Agencies that support the ARPANET. (See
CONTACTS, ARPANET Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. ) The group
considers and makes recommendations to DCA on operational activities and
services available on the ARPANET. It also serves as a forum for the exchange of ideas and information on the operation of the ARPANET and of future
networks of common interest.
The Sponsors Group normally meets semiannually. Special meetings may be
called by the Chairman, if the situation warrants it, prior to the next regularly
scheduled meeting. Meetings normally are held in the Washington, D. C. area,
but may be held at other locations.
Responsibilities of an ARPANET Sponsor are
To process all IMP/TIP and associated hardware requirements
through Mildep or agency channels to DCA Code 535 for
procurement.
. To process via DCA Code 535 all requests for access lines, host
interfaces, circuit rearrangements, and equipment moves.
To review for Approval/ Disapproval requests for connection by other sponsors or government agencies, of hosts / terminals to
IMPs/TIPs under his control.
To insure that all hosts have access control procedures
and standards to prevent unauthorized use. Periodically
having host accounts reviewed for removal of unauthorized
users.
• To insure that TIP liaisons change TIP Dial - In - Modem numbers as scheduled by DCA Code 535.
. To see that the Network Liaison promptly report host/ terminal connection changes as they occur to the NIC and the NCC.
To inform their nodes of ARPANET policies as published in the
Sponsors Group Minutes and DCA correspondence.
To inform DCA Code 535 of any significant continuing network
problems, and file Unsatisfactory Service Reports (USRs) to DCA
Code 535 with copies to BBN as necessary.
To attend the semiannual ARPANET Sponsors Group Meetings to
present problems, define user needs, make recommendations for
change in policy, and discuss related network matters.
. To validate requirements for distribution of ARPANET
documentation.
10
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
WHO MAY BE A SUBSCRIBER ON THE ARPANET
DOD USERS
Subject to the availability of assets, DoD activities will be connected to the
ARPANET provided the requests are processed through normal
communications validating channels.
NON - DOD U.S. GOVERNMENT ACTIVITIES
Requests for ARPANET service from non - DOD U.S. Government activities will
be considered by DCA on a case - by - case basis.
NON - GOVERNMENT U. S. ACTIVITIES
A DOD or other U. S. Government activity authorized to use the network
may sponsor, as a user, a non - government activity performing contract
work for the U. S. Government. Justification outlining benefits to the U. S.
Government for such access shall be provided to DCA by the sponsoring
activity. Cost for network services provided to non - government activities will be allocated to the sponsoring activity.
NON - U. S. ACTIVITIES
Non - U. S. activities will not be directly connected to the ARPANET.
to the ARPANET may be provided through the facilities of an authorized
user if coordinated with DCA.
INFORMATION ON PROCEDURES TO BECOME A SUBSCRIBER
U. S. Government activities requesting ARPANET service must apply to the
Director, Defense Communications Agency, ATTN : ARPANET Management
Branch, Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305. Detailed procedures are
contained in the ARPANET Information Brochure, which is available from DCA
Code 535 or from NTIS as AD A052672.
Criteria and standards for interface to the ARPANET are specified in the report:
Interface Message Processor: Specifications for the Interconnection of a Host
and an IMP, Rept. 1822, Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc., Cambridge, Mass. ,
May 1978 revision, available from NTIS as AD A055996. This report is
revised periodically . New criteria and standards developed jointly by DCA, the Military Services, and the Defense Agencies will be promulgated by the DCA.
All users are expected to meet ARPANET interface specifications.
11
ARPANET INFORMATION
FUNDING
The operation and maintenance (O&M) of the ARPANET backbone, i.e. , nodes,
interfaces, and internode communications circuits, is paid through the Communications Services Industrial Fund ( CSIF ) which is managed and operated by the Defense Communications Agency. The Defense Commercial Communications Office ( DECCO) has responsibility for all leasing actions which take place under the CSIF. This function includes normal contract management
activities for the ARPANET. All bills for the CSIF portion of the ARPANET are
paid by DECCO. Audits of contractors are performed by the Defense Contract
Audit Agency ( DCAA) at the request of DECCO. The vehicle used to request communication services is the ARPANET TSR which is forwarded to DECCO
from DCA Code 535 as the ARPANET manager. Under the working capital or revolving fund concept, predetermined subscriber rates are the basis for
recovering the cost of operating and maintaining the backbone network.
The estimated cost to operate and maintain the ARPANET backbone during a
fiscal year, divided by the estimated number of IMPs and TIPs in the network,
provides the annual cost per year per node:
Total O&M Cost
=
Annual Cost per IMP or TIP
# IMPs and # TIPs
All ARPANET customer activities will be billed monthly based on a
predetermined cost for each operational node in the backbone. The monthly rate for FY78 is approx. $ 6000 and for FY79 and FY80 approx. $ 6500.
SECURITY
The ARPANET communications subnet or 'backbone' contains security
features to insure privacy or the protection of classified defense information
transiting the network. Therefore, it is the responsibility of sponsors and those operating hosts on the network to take steps to protect information resident or
accessible through their host computers from access by unauthorized users,
and to provide protection against unauthorized access to classified information
which may reside or be accessible via their host computer link to the network.
There are no " login " procedures for initial network access. All access control
is provided at the host level.
A secure subnet is possible by providing hosts with a Private Line Interface ( PLI) . The PLI has been approved by the National Security Agency ( NSA) and
costs approximately $ 55,000 per copy. The user also has to provide a KG34.
The PLI subnet can include up to 128 hosts constrained to 32 nodes.
12
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
COMPLAINTS
A complaint center teletype is maintained at the NCC for users reporting
problems or seeking assistance. Receiving and processing complaints is not
purely an NCC function, thus an additional channel for reporting unsatisfactory service has been developed. The ARPANET Unsatisfactory Service Report (USR) has been established as the formal means of reporting deficiencies with respect to the operations of the ARPANET backbone communications.
Problems or complaints which cannot be resolved through normal channels
should be reported by means of the USR. The types of problems to be
included are, but are not limited to, the following:
Excessive response time
. Inadequate restoral procedures
. Unsatisfactory maintenance support
The User (Sponsor) must determine when service has reached an unsatisfactory point. The report may be sent over the ARPANET, AUTODIN, or by U.S. Mail.
Reports should be addressed to DCA Code 535 with information copies to the
NCC at BBN and any other activity as deemed appropriate by the originators.
( See CONTACTS section for addresses.)
USING RESOURCES ON THE ARPANET
Although the Resource Handbook describes resources available for use on the ARPANET, mention of a resource in the Handbook in no way guarantees user
access. Access to almost any resource, other than the network itself, is under
the control of the host on which the resource resides. In all cases it is
assumed that any resource described is available only to authorized users who have valid accounts on the host at which they wish to use a given resource.
Accounts should be negotiated with the ACCOUNTS contact or with the
LIAISON. (See PERSONNEL under any given host entry )
The ARPANET is intended to be used solely for the conduct of, or in support
of, official U. S. Government business.
The use of the ARPANET must not be in violation of information privacy laws
and is not intended to compete with existing commercial services.
13

ARPANET DIRECTORY GENERAL CONTACTS
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
GENERAL CONTACTS
TIP PHONE NUMBERS
The NIC does not provide TIP phone numbers to network users. Access to a
TIP is at the discretion of the Sponsor for a given TIP, and is not guaranteed .
To obtain a TIP phone number, contact the Liaison for the TIP to be accessed.
(See the HOST ACRONYMS section for a list of TIPs, their corresponding Liaison, and their geographical location . )

PROTOCOLS
Technical questions regarding network protocols should be sent to
Network Working Group Coordinator ( NWG)

ARPANET DIRECTORY NETWORK LIAISON
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
NETWORK LIAISON
The ARPANET Technical Liaison act as advisors to network users, the Network
Information Center, the Network Control Center, and the Defense Communications
Agency on technical matters relating to the ARPANET. The Liaison are the chief source of information about individual ARPANET hosts. They often contribute to
the design of network protocols and related software and make suggestions for needed changes and improvements through memos, RFCs (network technical
notes) , and participation in network working groups. The work they do is on a
volunteer basis, and they are in themselves a valuable network resource.
The Liaison are traditionally individuals trained in computer science or a related
field , and are familiar with the resources available at the host they represent.
Each host on the network has no more than one Technical Liaison ; however, the
same person may serve as liaison for more than one host. The Technical Liaison
are coordinated by the Manager of the Network Information Center.
For a list of the names, addresses, network mailboxes, and host affiliations of the
ARPANET Technical Liaison, see HOST ACRONYMS section .
1

Look for the year you want in the inder at left. The number opposite each year is the number of the calendar to use for that year.

ARPANET DIRECTORY INTRODUCTION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
BRIEF EXPLANATION OF THIS DIRECTORY
ATTENTION
The ARPANET Directory is the property of the Department of Defense. It is to be
used solely for the conduct of, or in support of, official U.S. government business.
Its use for advertising, mail distribution lists , or for any other unauthorized purpose is strictly prohibited . Any individuals or hosts who violate this prohibition will have
their listings deleted from both this directory and the online system directory.
NIC INFORMATION
Services and documents available from the Network Information Center (NIC)
are described in this section of the Directory.
ARPANET INFORMATION
General information, useful definitions, policies , and procedures for using the
ARPANET are included in this section.
CONTACTS
Lists general network contacts, as well as the ARPANET Sponsors and the
ARPANET Liaison.
INDIVIDUALS
Individuals who are authorized ARPANET users and who have supplied the proper information to the ARPANET Network Information Center are listed
alphabetically by last name in the INDIVIDUALS section of the directory. The
format is :
INDIVIDUAL'S NAME NIC IDENT
HARDCOPY - MAIL - ADDRESS
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS
PHONE NUMBER
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT
where
NIC IDENT = a unique code ( usually one's initials) by which the NIC
Identification System recognizes and locates an individual .
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS is in the form: USER -NAME@ HOST - NAME.
The HOST NAME portion identifies a computer (host) attached to the
ARPANET at which the individual receives delivery of his network mail . The USER NAME portion of the network mail address is the character sequence
by which that host identifies the user's incoming mail .
NOTE: The statement Network Address Unknown' indicates that no
network mail address was received by the NIC from the individual in
question .
1
INTRODUCTION
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT = the official identification code for
the host with which an individual is associated; or if no ARPANET host
exists, an identification code representing the organization with which the individual is associated.
NETWORK MAILBOX INDEX
This table is organized alphabetically by network mailbox along with the
corresponding individual's name. It is a subset of the INDIVIDUALS listing and indicates what individuals are associated with which mailboxes.
HOSTS AND ASSOCIATES
Hosts are computers connected to the ARPANET. There are three kinds of
hosts: SERVERS, USERs and TIPS. SERVERS have implemented SERVER
TELNET and are capable of providing services to remote users across the
network. USERs let individuals access resources elsewhere on the network, but
do not provide services of their own and have not implemented SERVER TELNET. TIPs are interface message processors with terminal connections.
They function as special - case users. Associates are network - related organizations that do not have hosts connected to the ARPANET. Hosts and associates are listed alphabetically by organization name in the format:
ORGANIZATION NAME OFFICIAL HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
and by host acronym in the format:
HOST NAME HOST ADDR STATUS SPONSOR NAME OF LIAISON
ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
LIAISON'S PHONE NO.
or by associate acronym in the format:
ASSOCIATE IDENT ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
where
OFFICIAL HOST NAME = a unique acronym , obtained through negotiation
with the NIC, by which a host is known on the ARPANET.
ASSOCIATE IDENT = an identification acronym for associate organizations,
assigned by the NIC or the sponsoring organization.
HOST NUMBER/ IMP NUMBER ASSIGNMENTS
The Host No./IMP No. Table specifies which hosts are attached to each IMP or TIP.
COMPUTERS
The Computer Tables list network hosts organized by computer configuration and by computer manufacturer.
-
-
2
ARPANET DIRECTORY NIC INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER SERVICES
WHAT THE NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER ( NIC) DOES
The NIC serves as a center for collection and dissemination of information
about the ARPANET. It is located at SRI International in Menlo Park, California.
The NIC was begun in 1970 as a research project to develop a prototypical network information center, and up until July 1 , 1975 was sponsored by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA ). Currently it is funded by the Defense Communications Agency (DCA) to provide the services outlined
below .
PUBLICATIONS
The Network Information Center publishes the following documents:
The ARPANET Directory - A directory of users and hosts on the ARPANET. It
gives the names, online and offline mail addresses, phone number, and host
affiliation of ARPANET users, as well as summary tables of host information.
The ARPANET Protocol Handbook - A collection of the currently accepted network protocols.
The ARPANET Resource Handbook
on the ARPANET.
- a compendium of the resources available
NICNOTES Informal newsnotes distributed online by the NIC to the Liaison
and other interested people. NICNOTES are primarily concerned with announcement of changes of hostnames and host addresses on the ARPANET.
ONLINE REFERENCE FILES
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET HOSTNAMES LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 66 dec) as
<NETINFO>HOSTS.TXT
This file contains the official list of hostnames and host addresses for hosts
attached to the ARPANET. It consists of hostname, host address , type of host (i.e. , USER, SERVER, or TIP) and host nickname, if any. It is accessible to any network user for reference, and is mainly used to update local
hostname recognition tables. The reference file meets criteria outlined in RFC 608.
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET LIAISON LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 66 dec) as
<NETINFO>LIAISON.TXT
This file contains name, U. S. mail address, network mail address, phone,
and host affiliation for each network Liaison.
3
NIC INFORMATION
THE LIAISON NETWORK MAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL (66 dec) as <NETINFO>LIAISON - SNDMSG.TXT
This file contains network mail addresses for all Network Liaison formatted
for online group distribution of messages via SNDMSG.
REQUEST FOR COMMENTS (RFCS)
Current Network Working Group ( NWG) papers, known as RFCs, are kept
online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL ( 66 dec) . These are maintained by the Coordinator of the NWG, currently Jon Postel, and are announced via an online distribution list . Each RFC remains online for at
least 21 days to give users a chance to obtain copies. Individuals wishing
to be added to the RFC notification list should contact Jon Postel
(POSTEL@ISIB) .
NIC/ QUERY
Most of the information contained in the Resource Handbook is maintained
online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL. This information may be viewed through the NIC/QUERY program . The query program is geared
toward novice or casual users and is available to all . (See ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES below. )
ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES
Connect to SRI - KL (66 dec) and type:
[ @] nic <CR>
where
@ = the SRI - KL TENEX herald
<CR> = a carriage return typed by the user
then follow the instructions that are printed out.
NOTE: Users may use this account for viewing reference files in the
NIC / Query system, but they may not use it to access other programs.
cannot be used for linking or loading the FTP program .
HARDCOPY DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION
The NIC maintains files of many hardcopy documents pertaining to the ARPANET. Although the NIC (since 9/74) does not officially distribute
hardcopy documents to network users, it will attempt to honor Interlibrary Loan
requests for items in the NIC collection that are not available in the open
literature. This service is provided to the extent that funds and staff permit and is not guaranteed.
4
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
ARPANET GENERAL INFORMATION
USEFUL DEFINITIONS
INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR ( IMP )
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to four host computers. The original IMPs and TIPs were Honeywell 316 and 516
machines. NOTE: There will not be any additional 316 or 516 IMPs added to the network as Honeywell has stopped manufacturing them .
TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR (TIP)
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to three host
computers and 63 terminals. Each terminal may be either asynchronous or
externally clocked, and may operate at speeds up to 2400 baud on input
and 19.2 kilobaud on output. Some types of intelligent terminals are also
supported.
PLURIBUS INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which can accomodate in excess of 18 host computers, depending upon
configuration. This type IMP has higher throughput capacity and can be
configured redundantly for improved reliability .
PLURIBUS TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR ( PTIP)
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which
can accomodate in excess of 12 hosts simultaneously with several hundred
terminals. Other characteristics are similar to the Honeywell TIPs.
HOST
A customer - owned computer which is connected to a host port on an IMP or TIP. Hosts may be categorized in two ways:
DISTANT Host A host which is more than 30 feet, but less than
2,000 feet, from an IMP or TIP.
LOCAL Host - A host located within 30 feet of an IMP or TIP.
VERY DISTANT Host - A host which is located over 2,000 feet from an
IMP or TIP and requires modems on its access line.
or
SERVER Host - A host that has implemented SERVER TELNET and is
capable of providing computer access to distant users via the network.
USER Host - A host that is not capable of providing computer access
across the network , but whose members may use the network to access
SERVER Hosts. NOTE: The port taken up by the terminal access on a
TIP is considered a special case User, although technically no computer
is attached to the TIP port.
5
ARPANET INFORMATION
TERMINAL
A teletypewriter, CRT, or similar unit which is connected to a terminal port
of a TIP.
INTERSWITCH TRUNKS
A circuit between packet switches (e.g., IMPs and TIPs) which is used to
pass packets through the network.
ACCESS LINE
A circuit from a host computer or terminal to an IMP or TIP. The circuit
may be a local cable or a transmission facility requiring modems.
ARPANET BACKBONE
The switching nodes (e.g., IMPs and TIPs ), interfaces, the communication lines interconnecting the nodes, and the Network Control Center (NCC) .
The backbone is also known as the communications subnet.
SPONSOR
A MILDEP, DOD Agency, or other U. S. Government Agency which is responsible for an ARPANET user ( s ) and reimburses DCA for the ARPANET
backbone costs. The Agency is authorized to sponsor a contractor or other
nongovernment activity for access to the ARPANET for the purpose of conducting official U. S. Government business. (See CONTACTS, ARPANET
Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. )
NODE
The packet switch; an IMP/TIP or Pluribus IMP/TIP.
WHAT THE ARPANET IS
The ARPANET is an operational, resource sharing, host - to - host network linking a wide variety of computers at research centers sponsored by Defense
Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) and other DoD and non - DoD activities in continental United States, Hawaii, Norway, and England.
The ARPANET orginated as a purely experimental network in late 1969 under
a research and development program sponsored by DARPA to advance the
state - of - the - art in computer internetting. The network was designed to
provide efficient communications between heterogeneous computers so that
hardware, software, and data resources could be conveniently and economically
shared by a wide community of users. As the network successfully attained its
initial design goals, additional users were authorized access to the network.
Today, the ARPANET provides support for a large number of DoD and non - DoD
government projects with an operational network of many nodes and host
computers.
Following the successful accomplishment of initial ARPANET design goals and the expansion of the network , it was considered appropriate to transfer the
responsibility for operation of the ARPANET from DARPA to the Defense Communications Agency ( DCA) . In July 1975, the DCA became the operational manager of the ARPANET.
6
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE ARPANET
The ARPANET is an operational, computerized, packet switching DoD digital
network which provides a capability for terminals or geographically separated
computers, called hosts, to communicate with each other. The host computers
often differ from one another in type, speed, word length, operating system,
and other characteristics. Each terminal or host computer is connected into the network through a small local node computer called an IMP or TIP. The
complete network is formed by interconnecting the IMPs through wideband communication lines ( normally 50,000 bits per second) supplied by common carriers.
Each node is programmed to receive and forward messages to the neighboring nodes in the network. During a typical operation, a host passes a message to
its node; the message is passed from node to node through the network until
it finally arrives at the destination IMP, which in turn passes it along to the destination host. This process normally takes less than 250 milliseconds.
Hosts communicate with each other via regular messages. A regular message
may vary in length from 96 to 8159 bits, the first 96 of which are control
bits called the leader. The leader is also used for sending control messages
between the host and its IMP or TIP (node ). The remainder of the message is
the data or text.
For each regular message, the host specifies a destination, consisting of node,
host, and handling type. These three parameters uniquely specify a connection between source and destination hosts. The handling type gives the connection
specific characteristics, such as priority or non - priority transmission. Additional
leader space has been reserved for a fourth parameter, to be used in future internetwork addressing. For each connection , messages are delivered to the
destination in the same order that they were transmitted by the source.
For each regular message, the host also specifies a 12 - bit identifier, the
message - ID. The message -ID, together with the destination of the message, is
used as the " name" of the message. The node uses this name to inform the
host of the disposition of the message. Therefore, if the host refrains from
re - using a particular message - ID value (to a given destination) until the node has responded about that message - ID, messages will remain uniquely identified
and the host can retransmit them in the event of a failure within the network.
After receiving a regular message from a host connected to it , a node breaks the message into several packets ( currently the maximum data bits per packet is 1008) and passes these through the network in the direction of the destination. Eventually, when all packets arrive at the destination , they are
reassembled to form the original message which is passed to the destination
host. The destination node returns a positive acknowledgment for receipt of
the message to the source host. This acknowledgment is called a Ready for
Next Message ( RFNM) and identifies the message being acknowledged by name. In some relatively rare cases, however, the message may not be delivered due to a node failure; line disruption , etc., in such cases an
Incomplete Transmission message will be returned to the source host instead of
a RFNM. In this case the message which was incompletely trnasmitted is also identified by name.
7
ARPANET INFORMATION
If a response from the destination node (either RFNM or Incomplete Transmission) is not delivered to the originating host, this condition will be
detected by the source node, which will automatically inquire of the destination node whether the original message was correctly received and repeat the inquiry until a response is received from the destination node. This inquiry
mechanism is timeout - driven, and each timeout period may vary between 30 and 45 seconds in length .
When a message arrives at its destination node, the leader is modified to indicate the source host, but the message - ID field is passed through unchanged. Thus, in addition to providing message identification between a
host and its local node, the message - ID can provide a means for hosts to identify messages between themselves.
Users of the ARPANET may access local or distant SERVER computers ( hosts)
over the network. They may also exchange messages, create realtime links
between users, transfer files from one computer to another, and submit batch
jobs to distant computers. For a more complete description of these processes,
see the ARPANET Protocol Handbook available from the NIC or the National
Technical Information System ( NTIS) , Springfield, Va. 22161 as AD A052594.
MANAGEMENT OF THE ARPANET
The Director, DCA controls system engineering and exercises operational
direction over those operating elements of ARPANET which are part of the backbone. ARPANET user equipment and terminals are non - backbone.
ARPANET users must be responsive to management instructions issued by the DCA regarding the ARPANET.
The Director, DCA, will monitor the effectiveness of the ARPANET on a
continuing basis, evaluate those matters which have major impact or will impact
adversely on the network , and direct action to alleviate or prevent such impact.
ARPANET responsibilities of DCA are
To set policies, procedures, and standards for the operation and
maintenance of the ARPANET.
. To approve new user access
. To lease the backbone and terminal access circuits
. To maintain the backbone hardware
. To approve changes in the network
To set access criteria
To plan, program , and budget for the resources
. To protect government assets
. To provide configuration control
. To coordinate activities impacting the network
. To act as Chairman of the Network Sponsors Group
8
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
. To evaluate the performance of the network
. To carry out topology studies
. To support the Network Information Center (NIC)
• To collect performance statistics
ARPANET POLICIES
ARPANET policies are outlined in the ARPANET Information Brochure available from the ARPANET Management Branch, Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305
or from NTIS as AD A052672.
ARPANET SOFTWARE MODIFICATIONS
There are two general procedures for software modifications: 1 ) patches to
correct deficiencies (bugs) in the operating program , 2) changes which are
identified and approved for implementation. The software for the IMPs and
TIPs is programmed in assembly language for maximum operating efficiency
and use of available software. Software changes are tested and debugged at
BBN prior to release. The software change releases are scheduled for testing
and implementation on Tuesdays between 0700 and 0900 Boston time.
To insure that users are fully aware of major software changes which may affect their operations, changes will be processed in the following manner:
. A specification will be developed for each approved program change proposal.
For those program changes viewed as having potential impact
on the users, the specifications will be coordinated with the
user prior to coding.
Subsequently, a Software Release Notice (SRN) will be
distributed to all users as far in advance as possible but not less than 30 days prior to implementation ( emergency changes excepted). The SRN will provide the data required to users to adjust to the system change being implemented.
THE NETWORK CONTROL CENTER ( NCC)
The Network Control Center (NCC) for the ARPANET is primarily concerned with the reliability of the network, particularly the detection of line failures and IMP
or TIP failures. In addition , the NCC monitors volumes of host traffic and line
traffic which can give advance warning of network elements whose capacity
may need to be increased and which can also be used for site usage
accounting. The NCC maintains other data , such as sense switches, auto restart, memory protect settings, etc. , and buffer usage for each IMP/ TIP. This
data is helpful in diagnosing IMP/TIP failures. Due to the constant monitoring
of the ARPANET at the NCC, the operational availability of the network is very
high (consistently in excess of 99 %) .
The NCC is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts and is operated by Bolt,
Beranek , and Newman, Inc. under contract to the Defense Communications
Agency. ( See also CONTACTS section. )
9
ARPANET INFORMATION
THE ARPANET SPONSORS GROUP
The ARPANET Sponsors Group is made up of representatives from the various
DoD or U. S. Government Agencies that support the ARPANET. (See CONTACTS, ARPANET Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. ) The group
considers and makes recommendations to DCA on operational activities and
services available on the ARPANET. It also serves as a forum for the exchange
of ideas and information on the operation of the ARPANET and of future
networks of common interest.
The Sponsors Group normally meets semiannually. Special meetings may be
called by the Chairman, if the situation warrants it, prior to the next regularly
scheduled meeting. Meetings normally are held in the Washington, D. C. area ,
but may be held at other locations.
Responsibilities of an ARPANET Sponsor are
To process all IMP/TIP and associated hardware requirements through Mildep or agency channels to DCA Code 535 for
procurement.
. To process via DCA Code 535 all requests for access lines, host
interfaces, circuit rearrangements, and equipment moves.
To review for Approval/ Disapproval requests for connection by other sponsors or government agencies, of hosts/ terminals to
IMPs/ TIPs under his control.
To insure that all hosts have access control procedures
and standards to prevent unauthorized use. Periodically
having host accounts reviewed for removal of unauthorized
users.
• To insure that TIP liaisons change TIP Dial - In - Modem numbers as
scheduled by DCA Code 535.
To see that the Network Liaison promptly report host/terminal
connection changes as they occur to the NIC and the NCC.
To inform their nodes of ARPANET policies as published in the
Sponsors Group Minutes and DCA correspondence.
To inform DCA Code 535 of any significant continuing network problems , and file Unsatisfactory Service Reports ( USRs) to DCA Code 535 with copies to BBN as necessary.
To attend the semiannual ARPANET Sponsors Group Meetings to
present problems, define user needs, make recommendations for
change in policy, and discuss related network matters.
To validate requirements for distribution of ARPANET
documentation.

ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
WHO MAY BE A SUBSCRIBER ON THE ARPANET
DOD USERS
Subject to the availability of assets, DoD activities will be connected to the
ARPANET provided the requests are processed through normal
communications validating channels.
NON - DOD U.S. GOVERNMENT ACTIVITIES
Requests for ARPANET service from non - DOD U.S. Government activities will
be considered by DCA on a case - by - case basis.
NON - GOVERNMENT U. S. ACTIVITIES
A DoD or other U. S. Government activity authorized to use the network
may sponsor, as a user, a non - government activity performing contract
work for the U. S. Government. Justification outlining benefits to the U. S. Government for such access shall be provided to DCA by the sponsoring
activity. Cost for network services provided to non - government activities will be allocated to the sponsoring activity.
NON - U. S. ACTIVITIES
Non - U . S. activities will not be directly connected to the ARPANET. Access
to the ARPANET may be provided through the facilities of an authorized
user if coordinated with DCA.
INFORMATION ON PROCEDURES TO BECOME A SUBSCRIBER
U. S. Government activities requesting ARPANET service must apply to the
Director, Defense Communications Agency, ATTN : ARPANET Management Branch, Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305. Detailed procedures are
contained in the ARPANET Information Brochure, which is available from DCA
Code 535 or from NTIS as AD A052672.
Criteria and standards for interface to the ARPANET are specified in the report:
Interface Message Processor: Specifications for the Interconnection of a Host
and an IMP, Rept. 1822, Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc. , Cambridge, Mass. ,
May 1978 revision, available from NTIS as AD A055996. This report is
revised periodically. New criteria and standards developed jointly by DCA, the
Military Services, and the Defense Agencies will be promulgated by the DCA.
All users are expected to meet ARPANET interface specifications.
11
ARPANET INFORMATION
FUNDING
The operation and maintenance (O&M) of the ARPANET backbone, i.e. , nodes,
interfaces, and internode communications circuits, is paid through the Communications Services Industrial Fund ( CSIF) which is managed and operated by the Defense Communications Agency. The Defense Commercial
Communications Office (DECCO) has responsibility for all leasing actions which
take place under the CSIF. This function includes normal contract management
activities for the ARPANET. All bills for the CSIF portion of the ARPANET are
paid by DECCO. Audits of contractors are performed by the Defense Contract
Audit Agency ( DCAA) at the request of DECCO. The vehicle used to request
communication services is the ARPANET TSR which is forwarded to DECCO
from DCA Code 535 as the ARPANET manager. Under the working capital or revolving fund concept, predetermined subscriber rates are the basis for
recovering the cost of operating and maintaining the backbone network.
The estimated cost to operate and maintain the ARPANET backbone during a
fiscal year, divided by the estimated number of IMPs and TIPs in the network,
provides the annual cost per year per node:
Total O&M Cost
Annual Cost per IMP or TIP
# IMPs and # TIPS
All ARPANET customer activities will be billed monthly based on a
predetermined cost for each operational node in the backbone. The monthly
rate for FY78 is approx. $ 6000 and for FY79 and FY80 approx. $6500.
SECURITY
The ARPANET communications subnet or ' backbone' contains no security features to insure privacy or the protection of classified defense information
transiting the network. Therefore, it is the responsibility of sponsors and those operating hosts on the network to take steps to protect information resident or
accessible through their host computers from access by unauthorized users,
and to provide protection against unauthorized access to classified information
which may reside or be accessible via their host computer link to the network.
There are no " login " procedures for initial network access. All access control
is provided at the host level .
A secure subnet is possible by providing hosts with a Private Line Interface
( PLI) . The PLI has been approved by the National Security Agency ( NSA) and costs approximately $ 55,000 per copy. The user also has to provide a KG34.
The PLI subnet can include up to 128 hosts constrained to 32 nodes.
12
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
COMPLAINTS
A complaint center teletype is maintained at the NCC for users reporting
problems or seeking assistance. Receiving and processing complaints is not
purely an NCC function , thus an additional channel for reporting unsatisfactory service has been developed. The ARPANET Unsatisfactory Service Report
(USR) has been established as the formal means of reporting deficiencies with
respect to the operations of the ARPANET backbone communications.
Problems or complaints which cannot be resolved through normal channels
should be reported by means of the USR. The types of problems to be included are, but are not limited to, the following:
. Excessive response time
Inadequate restoral procedures
Unsatisfactory maintenance support
The User (Sponsor) must determine when service has reached an unsatisfactory point. The report may be sent over the ARPANET, AUTODIN , or by U.S. Mail.
Reports should be addressed to DCA Code 535 with information copies to the
NCC at BBN and any other activity as deemed appropriate by the originators.
(See CONTACTS section for addresses .)
USING RESOURCES ON THE ARPANET
Although the Resource Handbook describes resources available for use on the ARPANET, mention of a resource in the Handbook in no way guarantees user
access. Access to almost any resource, other than the network itself, is under
the control of the host on which the resource resides. In all cases it is
assumed that any resource described is available only to authorized users who
have valid accounts on the host at which they wish to use a given resource .
Accounts should be negotiated with the ACCOUNTS contact or with the LIAISON. ( See PERSONNEL under any given host entry)
The ARPANET is intended to be used solely for the conduct of, or in support of, official U. S. Government business.
The use of the ARPANET must not be in violation of information privacy laws
and is not intended to compete with existing commercial services.

ARPANET DIRECTORY NETWORK LIAISON
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
NETWORK LIAISON
The ARPANET Technical Liaison act as advisors to network users, the Network
Information Center, the Network Control Center, and the Defense Communications
Agency on technical matters relating to the ARPANET. The Liaison are the chief
source of information about individual ARPANET hosts. They often contribute to the design of network protocols and related software and make suggestions for
needed changes and improvements through memos, RFCs (network technical
notes) , and participation in network working groups. The work they do is on a
volunteer basis, and they are in themselves a valuable network resource.
The Liaison are traditionally individuals trained in computer science or a related
field , and are familiar with the resources available at the host they represent.
Each host on the network has no more than one Technical Liaison; however, the
same person may serve as liaison for more than one host. The Technical Liaison
are coordinated by the Manager of the Network Information Center.
For a list of the names, addresses, network mailboxes, and host affiliations of the
ARPANET Technical Liaison, see HOST ACRONYMS section .
19
NIC INFORMATION
THE LIAISON NETWORK MAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL (66 dec) as
<NETINFO>LIAISON - SNDMSG.TXT
This file contains network mail addresses for all Network Liaison formatted
for online group distribution of messages via SNDMSG.
REQUEST FOR COMMENTS (RFCS)
Current Network Working Group ( NWG) papers, known as RFCs, are kept online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL ( 66 dec) . These are
maintained by the Coordinator of the NWG, currently Jon Postel, and are announced via an online distribution list . Each RFC remains online for at
least 21 days to give users a chance to obtain copies. Individuals wishing
to be added to the RFC notification list should contact Jon Postel
(POSTEL@ISIB) .
NIC/QUERY
Most of the information contained in the Resource Handbook is maintained
online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL. This information may be viewed through the NIC/QUERY program . The query program is geared
toward novice or casual users and is available to all . (See ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES below .)
ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES
Connect to SRI - KL (66 dec) and type:
[ @] nic <CR>
where
@ = the SRI - KL TENEX herald
<CR> = a carriage return typed by the user
then follow the instructions that are printed out.
NOTE: Users may use this account for viewing reference files in the
NIC / Query system, but they may not use it to access other programs. It cannot be used for linking or loading the FTP program .
HARDCOPY DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION
The NIC maintains files of many hardcopy documents pertaining to the ARPANET. Although the NIC (since 9/74) does not officially distribute
hardcopy documents to network users, it will attempt to honor Interlibrary Loan
requests for items in the NIC collection that are not available in the open literature. This service is provided to the extent that funds and staff permit and is not guaranteed.
4
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
ARPANET GENERAL INFORMATION
USEFUL DEFINITIONS
INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR ( IMP)
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to four host computers. The original IMPs and TIPs were Honeywell 316 and 516
machines. NOTE: There will not be any additional 316 or 516 IMPs added to the network as Honeywell has stopped manufacturing them.
TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR (TIP )
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to three host
computers and 63 terminals. Each terminal may be either asynchronous or externally clocked , and may operate at speeds up to 2400 baud on input
and 19.2 kilobaud on output. Some types of intelligent terminals are also
supported.
PLURIBUS INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which can accomodate in excess of 18 host computers, depending upon
configuration. This type IMP has higher throughput capacity and can be
configured redundantly for improved reliability.
PLURIBUS TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR ( PTIP)
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which
can accomodate in excess of 12 hosts simultaneously with several hundred
terminals. Other characteristics are similar to the Honeywell TIPS.
HOST
A customer - owned computer which is connected to a host port on an IMP
or TIP. Hosts may be categorized in two ways:
DISTANT Host A host which is more than 30 feet, but less than
2,000 feet, from an IMP or TIP.
LOCAL Host - A host located within 30 feet of an IMP or TIP.
VERY DISTANT Host - A host which is located over 2,000 feet from an
IMP or TIP and requires modems on its access line.
or
SERVER Host - A host that has implemented SERVER TELNET and is capable of providing computer access to distant users via the network.
USER Host - A host that is not capable of providing computer access
across the network, but whose members may use the network to access
SERVER Hosts. NOTE: The port taken up by the terminal access on a
TIP is considered a special case User, although technically no computer
is attached to the TIP port.
5
ARPANET INFORMATION
TERMINAL
A teletypewriter, CRT, or similar unit which is connected to a terminal port
of a TIP.
INTERSWITCH TRUNKS
A circuit between packet switches (e.g., IMPs and TIPs) which is used to pass packets through the network.
ACCESS LINE
A circuit from a host computer or terminal to an IMP or TIP. The circuit
may be a local cable or a transmission facility requiring modems.
ARPANET BACKBONE
The switching nodes (e.g., IMPs and TIPs) , interfaces, the communication
lines interconnecting the nodes, and the Network Control Center (NCC) .
The backbone is also known as the communications subnet.
SPONSOR
A MILDEP, DOD Agency, or other U. S. Government Agency which is
responsible for an ARPANET user(s) and reimburses DCA for the ARPANET backbone costs. The Agency is authorized to sponsor a contractor or other nongovernment activity for access to the ARPANET for the purpose of
conducting official U. S. Government business. (See CONTACTS, ARPANET
Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. )
NODE
The packet switch; an IMP/TIP or Pluribus IMP/TIP.
WHAT THE ARPANET IS
The ARPANET is an operational, resource sharing, host - to - host network linking
a wide variety of computers at research centers sponsored by Defense
Advanced Research Projects Agency ( DARPA) and other DoD and non - DoD activities in continental United States, Hawaii, Norway, and England.
The ARPANET orginated as a purely experimental network in late 1969 under
a research and development program sponsored by DARPA to advance the
state - of - the - art in computer internetting. The network was designed to provide efficient communications between heterogeneous computers so that hardware, software, and data resources could be conveniently and economically
shared by a wide community of users. As the network successfully attained its
initial design goals, additional users were authorized access to the network.
Today, the ARPANET provides support for a large number of DoD and non - DoD
government projects with an operational network of many nodes and host
computers.
Following the successful accomplishment of initial ARPANET design goals and the expansion of the network, it was considered appropriate to transfer the
responsibility for operation of the ARPANET from DARPA to the Defense
Communications Agency ( DCA) . In July 1975, the DCA became the operational manager of the ARPANET.
6
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE ARPANET
The ARPANET is an operational, computerized , packet switching DoD digital
network which provides a capability for terminals or geographically separated
computers, called hosts, to communicate with each other. The host computers often differ from one another in type, speed, word length , operating system ,
and other characteristics. Each terminal or host computer is connected into the network through a small local node computer called an IMP or TIP. The
complete network is formed by interconnecting the IMPs through wideband communication lines ( normally 50,000 bits per second) supplied by common
carriers.
Each node is programmed to receive and forward messages to the neighboring nodes in the network . During a typical operation, a host passes a message to
its node; the message is passed from node to node through the network until
it finally arrives at the destination IMP, which in turn passes it along to the
destination host. This process normally takes less than 250 milliseconds.
Hosts communicate with each other via regular messages. A regular message
may vary in length from 96 to 8159 bits, the first 96 of which are control
bits called the leader. The leader is also used for sending control messages
between the host and its IMP or TIP ( node) . The remainder of the message is
the data or text.
For each regular message, the host specifies a destination , consisting of node,
host, and handling type. These three parameters uniquely specify a connection
between source and destination hosts. The handling type gives the connection specific characteristics, such as priority or non - priority transmission . Additional leader space has been reserved for a fourth parameter, to be used in future
internetwork addressing. For each connection , messages are delivered to the
destination in the same order that they were transmitted by the source.
For each regular message, the host also specifies a 12 - bit identifier, the message - ID. The message - ID, together with the destination of the message, is
used as the " name" of the message. The node uses this name to inform the
host of the disposition of the message. Therefore, if the host refrains from
re - using a particular message - ID value (to a given destination ) until the node
has responded about that message - ID, messages will remain uniquely identified
and the host can retransmit them in the event of a failure within the network.
After receiving a regular message from a host connected to it, a node breaks
the message into several packets ( currently the maximum data bits per packet is 1008) and passes these through the network in the direction of the destination. Eventually, when all packets arrive at the destination, they are
reassembled to form the original message which is passed to the destination
host. The destination node returns a positive acknowledgment for receipt of
the message to the source host. This acknowledgment is called a Ready for Next Message ( RFNM) and identifies the message being acknowledged by
name. In some relatively rare cases, however, the message may not be delivered due to a node failure; line disruption, etc. , in such cases an Incomplete Transmission message will be returned to the source host instead of
a RFNM. In this case the message which was incompletely trnasmitted is also
identified by name.
7
ARPANET INFORMATION
If a response from the destination node (either RFNM or Incomplete Transmission) is not delivered to the originating host, this condition will be
detected by the source node, which will automatically inquire of the destination
node whether the original message was correctly received and repeat the inquiry until a response is received from the destination node. This inquiry
mechanism is timeout - driven, and each timeout period may vary between 30 and 45 seconds in length .
When a message arrives at its destination node, the leader is modified to
indicate the source host, but the message - ID field is passed through unchanged. Thus, in addition to providing message identification between a
host and its local node, the message - ID can provide a means for hosts to identify messages between themselves.
Users of the ARPANET may access local or distant SERVER computers (hosts)
over the network. They may also exchange messages, create realtime links
between users, transfer files from one computer to another, and submit batch
jobs to distant computers. For a more complete description of these processes,
see the ARPANET Protocol Handbook available from the NIC or the National
Technical Information System (NTIS) , Springfield, Va. 22161 as AD A052594.
MANAGEMENT OF THE ARPANET
The Director, DCA controls system engineering and exercises operational
direction over those operating elements of ARPANET which are part of the backbone. ARPANET user equipment and terminals are non - backbone.
ARPANET users must be responsive to management instructions issued by the
DCA regarding the ARPANET.
The Director, DCA, will monitor the effectiveness of the ARPANET on a
continuing basis, evaluate those matters which have major impact or will impact adversely on the network, and direct action to alleviate or prevent such impact.
ARPANET responsibilities of DCA are
To set policies, procedures, and standards for the operation and
maintenance of the ARPANET.
To approve new user access .
. To lease the backbone and terminal access circuits
. To maintain the backbone hardware
. To approve changes in the network
To set access criteria
To plan, program, and budget for the resources
. To protect government assets
To provide configuration control
. To coordinate activities impacting the network
To act as Chairman of the Network Sponsors Group
8
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
To evaluate the performance of the network
. To carry out topology studies
To support the Network Information Center ( NIC)
. To collect performance statistics
ARPANET POLICIES
ARPANET policies are outlined in the ARPANET Information Brochure available
from the ARPANET Management Branch, Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305 or from NTIS as AD A052672.
ARPANET SOFTWARE MODIFICATIONS
There are two general procedures for software modifications: 1 ) patches to
correct deficiencies (bugs) in the operating program , 2) changes which are identified and approved for implementation. The software for the IMPs and TIPs is programmed in assembly language for maximum operating efficiency and use of available software. Software changes are tested and debugged at BBN prior to release. The software change releases are scheduled for testing
and implementation on Tuesdays between 0700 and 0900 Boston time.
To insure that users are fully aware of major software changes which may
affect their operations, changes will be processed in the following manner:
A specification will be developed for each approved program
change proposal.
For those program changes viewed as having potential impact
on the users, the specifications will be coordinated with the
user prior to coding.
Subsequently, a Software Release Notice (SRN) will be
distributed to all users as far in advance as possible but not less than 30 days prior to implementation (emergency changes excepted ). The SRN will provide the data required to users to adjust to the system change being implemented.
THE NETWORK CONTROL CENTER ( NCC)
The Network Control Center (NCC) for the ARPANET is primarily concerned with the reliability of the network, particularly the detection of line failures and IMP
or TIP failures. In addition , the NCC monitors volumes of host traffic and line
traffic which can give advance warning of network elements whose capacity
may need to be increased and which can also be used for site usage
accounting. The NCC maintains other data, such as sense switches, auto restart, memory protect settings, etc., and buffer usage for each IMP/ TIP. This
data is helpful in diagnosing IMP/ TIP failures. Due to the constant monitoring
of the ARPANET at the NCC, the operational availability of the network is very
high ( consistently in excess of 99 %) .
The NCC is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts and is operated by Bolt,
Beranek, and Newman, Inc. under contract to the Defense Communications
Agency. (See also CONTACTS section. )
9
ARPANET INFORMATION
THE ARPANET SPONSORS GROUP
The ARPANET Sponsors Group is made up of representatives from the various
DoD or U. S. Government Agencies that support the ARPANET. (See CONTACTS, ARPANET Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. ) The group
considers and makes recommendations to DCA on operational activities and
services available on the ARPANET. It also serves as a forum for the exchange
of ideas and information on the operation of the ARPANET and of future
networks of common interest.
The Sponsors Group normally meets semiannually. Special meetings may be
called by the Chairman, if the situation warrants it , prior to the next regularly
scheduled meeting. Meetings normally are held in the Washington, D. C. area,
but may be held at other locations.
Responsibilities of an ARPANET Sponsor are
To process all IMP/ TIP and associated hardware requirements through Mildep or agency channels to DCA Code 535 for
procurement.
. To process via DCA Code 535 all requests for access lines, host
interfaces, circuit rearrangements, and equipment moves.
To review for Approval/Disapproval requests for connection by other sponsors or government agencies, of hosts/terminals to
IMPs/TIPs under his control.
To insure that all hosts have access control procedures
and standards to prevent unauthorized use. Periodically
having host accounts reviewed for removal of unauthorized
users.
. To insure that TIP liaisons change TIP Dial - In -Modem numbers as
scheduled by DCA Code 535.
To see that the Network Liaison promptly report host/ terminal
connection changes as they occur to the NIC and the NCC.
. To inform their nodes of ARPANET policies as published in the Sponsors Group Minutes and DCA correspondence.
To inform DCA Code 535 of any significant continuing network
problems, and file Unsatisfactory Service Reports (USRs) to DCA Code 535 with copies to BBN as necessary .
. To attend the semiannual ARPANET Sponsors Group Meetings to
present problems, define user needs, make recommendations for change in policy, and discuss related network matters .
. To validate requirements for distribution of ARPANET
documentation.

ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
