WHO MAY BE A SUBSCRIBER ON THE ARPANET
DOD USERS
Subject to the availability of assets, DoD activities will be connected to the
ARPANET provided the requests are processed through normal communications validating channels.
NON - DOD U.S. GOVERNMENT ACTIVITIES
Requests for ARPANET service from non - DoD U.S. Government activities will
be considered by DCA on a case - by - case basis.
NON - GOVERNMENT U. S. ACTIVITIES
A DOD or other U. S. Government activity authorized to use the network
may sponsor, as a user, a non - government activity performing contract
work for the U. S. Government. Justification outlining benefits to the U. S. Government for such access shall be provided to DCA by the sponsoring
activity. Cost for network services provided to non - government activities will be allocated to the sponsoring activity.
NON - U. S. ACTIVITIES
Non - U. S. activities will not be directly connected to the ARPANET. Access
to the ARPANET may be provided through the facilities of an authorized
user if coordinated with DCA.
INFORMATION ON PROCEDURES TO BECOME A SUBSCRIBER
U. S. Government activities requesting ARPANET service must apply to the
Director, Defense Communications Agency, ATTN: ARPANET Management Branch , Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305. Detailed procedures are
contained in the ARPANET Information Brochure, which is available from DCA
Code 535 or from NTIS as AD A052672.
Criteria and standards for interface to the ARPANET are specified in the report:
Interface Message Processor: Specifications for the Interconnection of a Host
and an IMP, Rept. 1822, Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc. , Cambridge, Mass. ,
May 1978 revision , available from NTIS as AD A055996. This report is
revised periodically. New criteria and standards developed jointly by DCA, the
Military Services, and the Defense Agencies will be promulgated by the DCA.
All users are expected to meet ARPANET interface specifications.
11
ARPANET INFORMATION
FUNDING
The operation and maintenance (O&M) of the ARPANET backbone, i.e. , nodes,
interfaces, and internode communications circuits, is paid through the
Communications Services Industrial Fund ( CSIF) which is managed and operated
by the Defense Communications Agency. The Defense Commercial Communications Office ( DECCO) has responsibility for all leasing actions which take place under the CSIF. This function includes normal contract management
activities for the ARPANET. All bills for the CSIF portion of the ARPANET are
paid by DECCO. Audits of contractors are performed by the Defense Contract
Audit Agency ( DCAA) at the request of DECCO. The vehicle used to request
communication services is the ARPANET TSR which is forwarded to DECCO
from DCA Code 535 as the ARPANET manager. Under the working capital or revolving fund concept, predetermined subscriber rates are the basis for recovering the cost of operating and maintaining the backbone network.
The estimated cost to operate and maintain the ARPANET backbone during a
fiscal year, divided by the estimated number of IMPs and TIPs in the network,
provides the annual cost per year per node:
Total O&M Cost
= Annual Cost per IMP or TIP
# IMPs and # TIPs
All ARPANET customer activities will be billed monthly based on a
predetermined cost for each operational node in the backbone. The monthly
rate for FY78 is approx. $6000 and for FY79 and FY80 approx. $ 6500.
SECURITY
The ARPANET communications subnet or ' backbone' contains no security features to insure privacy or the protection of classified defense information
transiting the network. Therefore, it is the responsibility of sponsors and those operating hosts on the network to take steps to protect information resident or
accessible through their host computers from access by unauthorized users,
and to provide protection against unauthorized access to classified information
which may reside or be accessible via their host computer link to the network .
There are no " login " procedures for initial network access. All access control
is provided at the host level .
A secure subnet is possible by providing hosts with a Private Line Interface
( PLI) . The PLI has been approved by the National Security Agency ( NSA) and
costs approximately $ 55,000 per copy. The user also has to provide a KG34.
The PLI subnet can include up to 128 hosts constrained to 32 nodes.
12
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
COMPLAINTS
A complaint center teletype is maintained at the NCC for users reporting
problems or seeking assistance. Receiving and processing complaints is not
purely an NCC function, thus an additional channel for reporting unsatisfactory
service has been developed . The ARPANET Unsatisfactory Service Report
(USR) has been established as the formal means of reporting deficiencies with respect to the operations of the ARPANET backbone communications.
Problems or complaints which cannot be resolved through normal channels
should be reported by means of the USR. The types of problems to be
included are, but are not limited to, the following:
. Excessive response time
. Inadequate restoral procedures
Unsatisfactory maintenance support
The User ( Sponsor) must determine when service has reached an unsatisfactory point. The report may be sent over the ARPANET, AUTODIN, or by U.S. Mail.
Reports should be addressed to DCA Code 535 with information copies to the NCC at BBN and any other activity as deemed appropriate by the originators.
(See CONTACTS section for addresses. )
USING RESOURCES ON THE ARPANET
Although the Resource Handbook describes resources available for use on the
ARPANET, mention of a resource in the Handbook in no way guarantees user access. Access to almost any resource, other than the network itself, is under
the control of the host on which the resource resides. In all cases it is
assumed that any resource described is available only to authorized users who
have valid accounts on the host at which they wish to use a given resource.
Accounts should be negotiated with the ACCOUNTS contact or with the LIAISON. (See PERSONNEL under any given host entry)
The ARPANET is intended to be used solely for the conduct of, or in support
of, official U. S. Government business.
The use of the ARPANET must not be in violation of information privacy laws
and is not intended to compete with existing commercial services.

GENERAL CONTACTS
TIP PHONE NUMBERS
The NIC does not provide TIP phone numbers to network users. Access to a
TIP is at the discretion of the Sponsor for a given TIP, and is not guaranteed.
To obtain a TIP phone number, contact the Liaison for the TIP to be accessed .
( See the HOST ACRONYMS section for a list of TIPs, their corresponding Liaison, and their geographical location. )

ARPANET DIRECTORY NETWORK LIAISON
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
NETWORK LIAISON
The ARPANET Technical Liaison act as advisors to network users, the Network
Information Center, the Network Control Center, and the Defense Communications
Agency on technical matters relating to the ARPANET. The Liaison are the chief source of information about individual ARPANET hosts. They often contribute to
the design of network protocols and related software and make suggestions for needed changes and improvements through memos, RFCs (network technical
notes) , and participation in network working groups. The work they do is on a
volunteer basis, and they are in themselves a valuable network resource.
The Liaison are traditionally individuals trained in computer science or a related
field , and are familiar with the resources available at the host they represent.
Each host on the network has no more than one Technical Liaison; however, the
same person may serve as liaison for more than one host. The Technical Liaison
are coordinated by the Manager of the Network Information Center.
For a list of the names, addresses, network mailboxes, and host affiliations of the
ARPANET Technical Liaison , see HOST ACRONYMS section.

ARPANET DIRECTORY COMPUTERS BY HOST
NIC 46099 Dec. 1978
COMPUTER CONFIGURATIONS
EXPLANATION
This table is divided into two parts. The first part is organized by Host Name Acronyms and
the second by Host Address. ( For a definition of host name acronyms, see the HOST ACRONYMS table. )
For each host listed there is a description of the computer configuration for that host. The first computer mentioned in this description is attached to the IMP and is by definition the ' host'
computer. Other computers are attached to the host computer as indicated by the arrows.
Text enclosed in parentheses () after the name of a computer describes the operating system in
use on that computer.
Text enclosed in brackets [ ] indicates a computer that is in transition, either in the process of
coming up or of being removed.
Type designations are:
S
a
S Server host
U User host
T = TIP
VDH = Very distant host
NOTE: The configuration of machines on the ARPANET changes often, so this table undoubtedly
contains inaccuracies. Send corrections or additions to FEINLER@SRI - KL.
241

ii
ARPANET DIRECTORY INTRODUCTION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
BRIEF EXPLANATION OF THIS DIRECTORY
ATTENTION
The ARPANET Directory is the property of the Department of Defense. It is to be
used solely for the conduct of, or in support of, official U.S. government business.
The use of this book or its data base for advertising, mail distribution lists, or for
any other unauthorized purpose is strictly prohibited . Any individuals or hosts who
violate this prohibition will have their listings deleted from both this directory and the online system directory.
NIC INFORMATION
Services and documents available from the Network Information Center ( NIC)
are described in this section of the Directory.
ARPANET INFORMATION
General information, useful definitions, policies, and procedures for using the
ARPANET are included in this section .
CONTACTS
Lists general network contacts, as well as the ARPANET Sponsors and the
ARPANET Liaison.
INDIVIDUALS
Individuals who are authorized ARPANET users and who have supplied the proper information to the ARPANET Network Information Center are listed
alphabetically by last name in the INDIVIDUALS section of the directory. The
format is:
INDIVIDUAL'S NAME NIC IDENT
HARDCOPY - MAIL - ADDRESS
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS
PHONE NUMBER
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT
where
NIC IDENT = a unique code (usually one's initials) by which the NIC
Identification System recognizes and locates an individual .
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS is in the form : USER -NAME @ HOST -NAME.
The HOST NAME portion identifies a computer ( host) attached to the ARPANET at which the individual receives delivery of his network mail . The
USER NAME portion of the network mail address is the character sequence by which that host identifies the user's incoming mail .
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT = the official identification code for
the host with which an individual is associated; or if no ARPANET host
exists, an identification code representing the organization with which the
individual is associated .
1
INTRODUCTION
NETWORK MAILBOX INDEX
This index is organized alphabetically by network mailbox along with the corresponding
individual's name. It is a subset of the INDIVIDUALS listing and indicates what
individuals are associated with which mailboxes.
HOSTS AND ASSOCIATES
Hosts are computers connected to the ARPANET. There are three kinds of hosts:
SERVERS, USERs and TIPS. SERVERS have implemented SERVER TELNET and are
capable of providing services to remote users across the network. USERs let
individuals access resources elsewhere on the network, but do not provide services of
their own and have not implemented SERVER TELNET. TIPs are special - case interface
message processors ( IMPs) which have one port dedicated to terminal connections.
Associates are network - related organizations that do not have hosts connected to the ARPANET. Hosts and associates are listed alphabetically by organization name in the
format:
ORGANIZATION NAME OFFICIAL HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION ACRONYM
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
and by host acronym in the format:
OFFICIAL HOST NAME ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
or by associate acronym in the format:
ASSOCIATE ACRONYM ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
where
OFFICIAL HOST NAME = a unique acronym, obtained through negotiation with the
NIC, by which a host is known on the ARPANET.
ASSOCIATE IDENT = an identification acronym for associate organizations, assigned
by the NIC or the sponsoring organization .
HOST NUMBER/IMP NUMBER ASSIGNMENTS
The Host No./IMP No. Table specifies which hosts are attached to each IMP or TIP.
COMPUTERS
The Computer Tables list network hosts organized by computer configuration and by computer manufacturer.
2
ARPANET DIRECTORY NIC INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER SERVICES
WHAT THE NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER ( NIC ) DOES
The NIC serves as a center for collection and dissemination of information about the ARPANET. It is located at SRI International in Menlo Park, California .
The NIC was begun in 1970 as a research project to develop a prototypical
network information center, and up until July 1 , 1975 was sponsored by the
Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) . Currently it is funded by the Defense Communications Agency ( DCA) to provide the services outlined
below.
PUBLICATIONS
The Network Information Center publishes the following documents:
The ARPANET Directory - A directory of users and hosts on the ARPANET. It
gives the names, online and offline mail addresses, phone number, and host
affiliation of ARPANET users, as well as summary tables of host information.
The ARPANET Protocol Handbook - A collection of the currently accepted ARPANET network protocols.
The ARPANET Resource Handbook - a compendium of the resources available
on the ARPANET.
The NSW Reseource Handbook - A compendium of contacts and resources
available for use via the National Software Works project.
NICNOTES Informal newsnotes distributed online by the NIC to the Liaison
and other interested people. NICNOTES are primarily concerned with announcement of changes of host names and host addresses on the ARPANET.
ONLINE REFERENCE FILES
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET HOST NAMES LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL (66 dec ) as <NETINFO>HOSTS.TXT
This file contains the official list of host names and host addresses for hosts attached to the ARPANET. It consists of host name, host address,
type of host ( i.e. , USER, SERVER, or TIP) and host nickname, if any. It is accessible to any network user for reference, and is mainly used to update local host name recognition tables. The reference file meets criteria outlined in RFC 608 which requires that host address be cited as decimal numbers.
An additional ASCII sequential file
<NETINFO>NHOSTS.TXT
is also available from SRI - KL. This file is the same as
<NETINFO>HOSTS.TXT except that it contains host addresses in the HOST
#/IMP # format, and includes addresses for hosts on IMPs numbered higher
than 63, and hosts on ports numbered greater than 3 .
3
NIC INFORMATION
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET LIAISON LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 66 dec ) as
<NETINFO>LIAISON.TXT
This file contains name, U. S. mail address, network mail address, phone,
and host affiliation for each network Liaison.
THE LIAISON NETWORK MAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 66 dec) as
<NETINFO>LIAISON - SNDMSG.TXT
This file contains network mail addresses for all Network Liaison formatted
for online group distribution of messages via most mail programs.
REQUEST FOR COMMENTS ( RFCS)
Current Network Working Group (NWG) papers, known as RFCs, are kept
online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI – KL (66 dec) . These are maintained by the Coordinator of the NWG, currently Jon Postel, and are
announced via an online distribution list. Each RFC remains online for at
least 21 days to give users a chance to obtain copies. Individuals wishing
to be added to the RFC notification list should contact Jon Postel
( POSTEL @ ISIB ).
NIC/QUERY
Most of the information contained in the ARPANET Resource Handbook is
maintained online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL. This information
may be viewed through the NIC/QUERY program . The query program is geared toward novice or casual users and is available to all . (See ACCESS
TO NIC ONLINE FILES below. )
WHOIS
The NIC has implemented an experimental ARPANET server, called WHOIS,
that makes fast query / response transactions over the network to provide identification of network users ( name, U.S. mail address, network mailbox,
phone, and host affiliation) .
To access WHOIS, type
whois LASTNAME <SP><CR>
after logging into a host on which the user program resides ( see below ).
Type
whois ? <CR>
to get help.
As of November 1979 the WHOIS program was running on USC - ISI ,
USC - ISIB , USC - ISIE, RADC - TOPS20, SRI - KL, SRI - KA, OFFICE - 1 , OFFICE - 2 ,
and OFFICE - 3. It will be running on more ARPANET computers soon.
Contact FEINLER @ SRI - KL for information.
-
-
-
4
ARPANET DIRECTORY NIC INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
ACCESS TO NIC ONLINE FILES
Connect to SRI - KL ( 66 dec) and type:
[ @] nic <CR>
where
3
@ the SRI - KL TENEX herald
<CR> = a carriage return typed by the user
then follow the instructions that are printed out.
NOTE: Users may use this account for viewing reference files in the
NIC / Query system , but they may not use it to access other programs. It cannot be used for linking or loading the FTP program.
HARDCOPY DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION
The NIC maintains files of many hardcopy documents pertaining to the
ARPANET. Although the NIC (since 9/74) does not officially distribute
hardcopy documents to network users, it will attempt to honor Interlibrary Loan
requests for items in the NIC collection that are not available in the open
literature. This service is provided to the extent that funds and staff permit and is not guaranteed.
5

ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
ARPANET GENERAL INFORMATION
USEFUL DEFINITIONS
INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR ( IMP)
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to four host
computers. The original IMPs and TIPs were Honeywell 316 and 516
machines. NOTE: There will not be any additional 316 or 516 IMPs added to the network as Honeywell has stopped manufacturing them .
TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR (TIP)
A store and forward packet switch which can accomodate up to three host
computers and 63 terminals. Each terminal may be either asynchronous or externally clocked , and may operate at speeds up to 2400 baud on input
and 19.2 kilobaud on output. Some types of intelligent terminals are also
supported.
PLURIBUS INTERFACE MESSAGE PROCESSOR
A store and forward packet switch based on multiprocessor technology which can accomodate in excess of 18 host computers, depending upon
configuration . This type IMP, produced by Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc. ( BBN) , has higher throughput capacity and can be configured redundantly for improved reliability .
PLURIBUS TERMINAL INTERFACE PROCESSOR ( PTIP)
A store and forward packet switch produced by BBN and based on multiprocessor technology. It can accomodate in excess of 12 hosts
simultaneously with several hundred terminals. Other characteristics are similar to the Honeywell TIPS.
HOST
A customer - owned computer which is connected to a host port on an IMP
or TIP. Hosts may be categorized in two ways:
DISTANT Host A host which is more than 30 feet, but less than
2,000 feet , from an IMP or TIP.
LOCAL Host A host located within 30 feet of an IMP or TIP.
VERY DISTANT Host A host which is located over 2,000 feet from an
IMP or TIP and requires modems on its access line .
or
SERVER Host - A host that has implemented SERVER TELNET and is
capable of providing computer access to distant users via the network.
7
ARPANET INFORMATION
USER Host - A host that is not capable of providing computer access
across the network, but whose members may use the network to access
SERVER Hosts. NOTE: The port taken up by the terminal access on a
TIP is considered a special case User, although technically no computer
is attached to the TIP port.
TERMINAL
A teletypewriter, CRT, or similar unit which is connected to a terminal port
of a TIP.
INTERSWITCH TRUNKS
A circuit between packet switches (e.g. , IMPs and TIPs) which is used to
pass packets through the network.
ACCESS LINE
A circuit from a host computer or terminal to an IMP or TIP. The circuit
may be a local cable or a transmission facility requiring modems.
ARPANET BACKBONE
The switching nodes (e.g. , IMPs and TIPs) , interfaces, the communication lines interconnecting the nodes, and the Network Control Center ( NCC) .
The backbone is also known as the communications subnet.
SPONSOR
A MILDEP, DOD Agency, or other U. S. Government Agency which is responsible for an ARPANET user(s) and reimburses DCA for the ARPANET
backbone costs. The Agency is authorized to sponsor a contractor or other
nongovernment activity for access to the ARPANET for the purpose of conducting official U. S. Government business. ( See CONTACTS, ARPANET
Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. )
NODE
The packet switch; an IMP/TIP or Pluribus IMP/ TIP.
WHAT THE ARPANET IS
The ARPANET is an operational, resource sharing, host - to - host network linking a wide variety of computers at research centers sponsored by Defense
Advanced Research Projects Agency ( DARPA) and other DoD and non - DoD
activities in continental United States, Hawaii , Norway, and England .
The ARPANET orginated as a purely experimental network in late 1969 under
a research and development program sponsored by DARPA to advance the state - of - the - art in computer internetting. The network was designed to provide efficient communications between heterogeneous computers so that hardware, software, and data resources could be conveniently and economically
shared by a wide community of users. As the network successfully attained its initial design goals , additional users were authorized access to the network.
Today, the ARPANET provides support for a large number of DoD and non - DoD
government projects with an operational network of many nodes and host
computers.
8
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
Following the successful accomplishment of initial ARPANET design goals and
the expansion of the network, it was considered appropriate to transfer the responsibility for operation of the ARPANET from DARPA to the Defense
Communications Agency ( DCA) . In July 1975, the DCA became the operational
manager of the ARPANET.
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE ARPANET
The ARPANET is an operational , computerized, packet switching DoD digital network which provides a capability for terminals or geographically separated
computers, called hosts, to communicate with each other. The host computers
often differ from one another in type, speed, word length , operating system,
and other characteristics. Each terminal or host computer is connected into the network through a small local node computer called an IMP or TIP. The complete network is formed by interconnecting the IMPs through wideband
communication lines ( normally 50,000 bits per second) supplied by common carriers.
Each node is programmed to receive and forward messages to the neighboring
nodes in the network. During a typical operation , a host passes a message to its node; the message is passed from node to node through the network until
it finally arrives at the destination IMP, which in turn passes it along to the
destination host. This process normally takes less than 250 milliseconds.
Hosts communicate with each other via regular messages. A regular message
may vary in length from 96 to 8159 bits, the first 96 of which are control
bits called the leader. The leader is also used for sending control messages
between the host and its IMP or TIP (node) . The remainder of the message is
the data or text.
For each regular message, the host specifies a destination , consisting of node,
host, and handling type. These three parameters uniquely specify a connection between source and destination hosts. The handling type gives the connection specific characteristics, such as priority or non - priority transmission. Additional
leader space has been reserved for a fourth parameter, to be used in future
internetwork addressing. For each connection , messages are delivered to the
destination in the same order that they were transmitted by the source.
For each regular message, the host also specifies a 12 - bit identifier, the
message - ID. The message - ID, together with the destination of the message, is
used as the " name " of the message. The node uses this name to inform the host of the disposition of the message. Therefore, if the host refrains from
re - using a particular message - ID value (to a given destination) until the node has responded about that message - ID, messages will remain uniquely identified
and the host can retransmit them in the event of a failure within the network.
9
ARPANET INFORMATION
After receiving a regular message from a host connected to it, a node breaks
the message into several packets (currently the maximum data bits per packet
is 1008) and passes these through the network in the direction of the destination. Eventually, when all packets arrive at the destination, they are
reassembled to form the original message which is passed to the destination
host. The destination node returns a positive acknowledgment for receipt of
the message to the source host. This acknowledgment is called a Ready for
Next Message ( RFNM) and identifies the message being acknowledged by
name. In some relatively rare cases, however, the message may not be delivered due to a node failure; line disruption, etc., in such cases an
Incomplete Transmission message will be returned to the source host instead of
a RFNM. In this case the message which was incompletely transmitted is also identified by name.
If a response from the destination node (either RFNM or Incomplete
Transmission) is not delivered to the originating host, this condition will be
detected by the source node, which will automatically inquire of the destination
node whether the original message was correctly received and repeat the
inquiry until a response is received from the destination node. This inquiry
mechanism is timeout - driven, and each timeout period may vary between 30
and 45 seconds in length.
When a message arrives at its destination node, the leader is modified to indicate the source host, but the message - ID field is passed through unchanged. Thus, in addition to providing message identification between a
host and its local node, the message - ID can provide a means for hosts to identify messages between themselves.
Users of the ARPANET may access local or distant SERVER computers ( hosts)
over the network . They may also exchange messages, create realtime links
between users, transfer files from one computer to another, and submit batch
jobs to distant computers. For a more complete description of these processes,
see the ARPANET Protocol Handbook available from the NIC or the National
Technical Information System ( NTIS) , Springfield, Va. 22161 as AD A052594.
MANAGEMENT OF THE ARPANET
The Director, DCA controls system engineering and exercises operational
direction over those operating elements of ARPANET which are part of the
backbone. ARPANET user equipment and terminals are non - backbone.
ARPANET users must be responsive to management instructions issued by the DCA regarding the ARPANET.
The Director, DCA, will monitor the effectiveness of the ARPANET on a
continuing basis, evaluate those matters which have major impact or will impact
adversely on the network, and direct action to alleviate or prevent such impact.
ARPANET responsibilities of DCA are
. To set policies, procedures, and standards for the operation and
maintenance of the ARPANET.
. To approve new user access
To lease the backbone and terminal access circuits
To maintain the backbone hardware
10
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
. To approve changes in the network
. To set access criteria
To plan, program, and budget for the resources .
. To protect government assets
. To provide configuration control
. To coordinate activities impacting the network
. To act as Chairman of the Network Sponsors Group
To evaluate the performance of the network
. To carry out topology studies
To support the Network Information Center ( NIC) .
. To collect performance statistics
ARPANET POLICIES
ARPANET policies are outlined in the ARPANET Information Brochure available from the ARPANET Management Branch, Code 535, Washington , D. C. 20305
or from NTIS as AD A052672.
ARPANET SOFTWARE MODIFICATIONS
There are two general procedures for software modifications: 1 ) patches to correct deficiencies ( bugs) in the operating program , 2 ) changes which are identified and approved for implementation . The software for the IMPs and
TIPs is programmed in assembly language for maximum operating efficiency and use of available software. Software changes are tested and debugged at
BBN prior to release. The software change releases are scheduled for testing and implementation on Tuesdays between 0700 and 0900 Boston time.
To insure that users are fully aware of major software changes which may affect their operations , changes will be processed in the following manner:
A specification will be developed for each approved program
change proposal .
For those program changes viewed as having potential impact on the users, the specifications will be coordinated with the
user prior to coding.
Subsequently, a Software Release Notice (SRN) will be
distributed to all users as far in advance as possible but not less than 30 days prior to implementation ( emergency changes
excepted) . The SRN will provide the data required to users to
adjust to the system change being implemented .
11
ARPANET INFORMATION
THE NETWORK CONTROL CENTER ( NCC)
The Network Control Center ( NCC) for the ARPANET is primarily concerned with the reliability of the network, particularly the detection of line failures and IMP or TIP failures. In addition , the NCC monitors volumes of host traffic and line
traffic which can give advance warning of network elements whose capacity
may need to be increased and which can also be used for site usage
accounting. The NCC maintains other data, such as sense switches, auto restart, memory protect settings, etc. , and buffer usage for each IMP/TIP. This
data is helpful in diagnosing IMP/ TIP failures . Due to the constant monitoring
of the ARPANET at the NCC, the operational availability of the network is very high (consistently in excess of 99 %) .
The NCC is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts and is operated by Bolt,
Beranek, and Newman, Inc. under contract to the Defense Communications
Agency. (See also CONTACTS section . )
THE ARPANET SPONSORS GROUP
The ARPANET Sponsors Group is made up of representatives from the various
DoD or U. S. Government Agencies that support the ARPANET. ( See CONTACTS, ARPANET Sponsors, for a list of network sponsors. ) The group
considers and makes recommendations to DCA on operational activities and
services available on the ARPANET. It also serves as a forum for the exchange
of ideas and information on the operation of the ARPANET and of future
networks of common interest.
The Sponsors Group normally meets semiannually. Special meetings may be
called by the Chairman, if the situation warrants it , prior to the next regularly
scheduled meeting. Meetings normally are held in the Washington, D. C. area,
but may be held at other locations.
Responsibilities of an ARPANET Sponsor are
To process all IMP/TIP and associated hardware requirements
through Mildep or agency channels to DCA Code 535 for
procurement .
To process via DCA Code 535 all requests for access lines, host interfaces, circuit rearrangements, and equipment moves.
To review for Approval/ Disapproval requests for connection by other sponsors or government agencies, of hosts/ terminals to
IMPs/TIPs under his control .
To insure that all hosts have access control procedures
and standards to prevent unauthorized use. Periodically
having host accounts reviewed for removal of unauthorized
users.
• To insure that TIP liaisons change TIP Dial - In - Modem numbers as
scheduled by DCA Code 535.
. To see that the Network Liaison promptly report host/terminal connection changes as they occur to the NIC and the NCC.
12
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
To inform their nodes of ARPANET policies as published in the
Sponsors Group Minutes and DCA correspondence.
To inform DCA Code 535 of any significant continuing network
problems, and file Unsatisfactory Service Reports (USRs) to DCA
Code 535 with copies to BBN as necessary.
To attend the semiannual ARPANET Sponsors Group Meetings to
present problems, define user needs, make recommendations for
change in policy, and discuss related network matters.
To validate requirements for distribution of ARPANET documentation.
THE ARPANET TECHNICAL LIAISON GROUP
The ARPANET Technical Liaison act as advisors to network users, the Network Information Center, the Network Control Center, and the Defense
Communications Agency on technical matters relating to the ARPANET. The
Liaison are the chief source of information about individual ARPANET hosts.
They often contribute to the design of network protocols and related software
and make suggestions for needed changes and improvements through memos,
RFCs (network technical notes) , and participation in network working groups.
The work they do is on a volunteer basis, and they are in themselves a
valuable network resource.
The Liaison are traditionally individuals trained in computer science or a related
field , and are familiar with the resources available at the host they represent.
Each host on the network has no more than one Technical Liaison ; however,
the same person may serve as liaison for more than one host. The Technical
Liaison are coordinated by the Manager of the Network Information Center,
currently E. Feinler (FEINLER@SRI - KL) .
For a list of the names, network mailboxes, and host affiliations of the
ARPANET Technical Liaison , see the NETWORK LIAISON section .
Responsibilities of an ARPANET Liaison are
Help monitor the ARPANET from unauthorized use. Permission to attach
hosts or other equipment to the ARPANET can only be granted by a
sponsoring agency. The Liaison should refer all requests for such attachments to DCA. Permission to use existing host resources can only
be granted by authorized host administrators to users with valid
accounts. The Liaison should refer all requests for such access to the
poper administrators. If it is possible to gain access to the ARPANET
from a tributary terminal off a host via the IMP - HOST connection , it is
the responsibility of that host to prevent illegal use. Distribution of TIP
dial - in numbers is entrusted to the TIP Liaison. Evidence of
unauthorized use of these numbers should be reported to DCA.
13
ARPANET INFORMATION
Upon completion of new host or terminal hardware installation and prior
to the new user passing traffic , contact DCA Code 535 via telephone or
ARPANET for final validation . DCA will then instruct BBN to set
host/terminal parameters to accept traffic . The Liaison should also
provide the NIC via telephone or ARPANET with his or her full name,
address, phone number, and network mailbox ( if this has not already been done) , as well as the host name, host address, operating system,
and computer configuration for any new hosts.
Help coordinate equipment moves or installations, or circuit moves or
installations affecting the ARPANET backbone or the IMPs and/or TIPs.
The Liaison will be sent info copies of Telecommunications Service
Requests (TSRs) from DCA, informing them of any changes in backbone
circuitry, terminal and/or host additions/deletions. They should help coordinate access to the IMP or TIP by TEL CO or BBN to peform actions called for in the TSRs. Unless a TSR has been received
authorizing equipment moves/installations or circuit moves/additions, no
such moves or installations should be made without contacting DCA Code 535 for authorization. ( Normal maintenance actions are excluded .)
If a TIP Liaison , forward to DCA Code 535 a quarterly TIP inventory.
The format for this report is available from DCACODE535@ISI . The
inventory is due by the 15th of January, April , July, and October of each
year. ( RCS #DCA( Q) 530-49) . Transmission via ARPANET is acceptable.
In the first five working days of each month the NIC will provide via the ARPANET a table of ARPANET Host Names, Liaison, and Sponsors.
Liaison should reveiw entries on this list pertaining to their TIPs or Hosts
for accuracy and provide any changes as soon as possible to the NIC.
They should also update their host recognition tables.
Provide the NIC with a description of equipment, software, people, and
interests pertaining to their designated hosts in accordance with the
formats outlined by the NIC.
Provide the NIC with updated personnel information for the ARPANET
Directory and online Identification Data Base and WHOIS server.
Keep local users informed about procedures and happenings related to the ARPANET. The Liaison will be the recipient of official messages sent
out about the ARPANET. These messages should be 'posted ' and/or
passed on to local users, administrators, or other interested personnel.
Serve as local contact for their host(s) . If an ARPANET user does not
know how to locate a particular resource, or how to handle a problem at
the host level , and does not know whom to contact, he can ask the
Network Liaison at the host he is trying to use to assist him . The Liaison can either help the user directly or refer him to the proper
contact.
Inform the NCC and DCA of network backbone problems and network
software bugs, and generate Unsatisfactory Service Reports as necessary.
See that ARPANET protocols are implemented properly at the host level .
(This activity may be designated to someone other than the Liaison.
However, the Liaison is expected to be the contact for protocol information distributed to the hosts and to see that the right person
receives it . )

ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
WHO MAY BE A SUBSCRIBER ON THE ARPANET
DOD USERS
Subject to the availability of assets, DoD activities will be connected to the ARPANET provided the requests are processed through normal communications validating channels.
NON - DOD U.S. GOVERNMENT ACTIVITIES
Requests for ARPANET service from non - DOD U.S. Government activities will
be considered by DCA on a case - by - case basis.
NON - GOVERNMENT U. S. ACTIVITIES
A DoD or other U. S. Government activity authorized to use the network
may sponsor, as a user, a non - government activity performing contract
work for the U. S. Government. Justification outlining benefits to the U. S.
Government for such access shall be provided to DCA by the sponsoring
activity. Cost for network services provided to non - government activities will be allocated to the sponsoring activity.
NON - U. S. ACTIVITIES
Non - U. S. activities will not be directly connected to the ARPANET. Access
to the ARPANET may be provided through the facilities of an authorized
user if coordinated with DCA.
INFORMATION ON PROCEDURES TO BECOME A SUBSCRIBER
U. S. Government activities requesting ARPANET service must apply to the Director, Defense Communications Agency, ATTN: ARPANET Management
Branch, Code 535, Washington, D. C. 20305. Detailed procedures are
contained in the ARPANET Information Brochure, which is available from DCA
Code 535 or from NTIS as AD A052672.
Criteria and standards for interface to the ARPANET are specified in the report:
Interface Message Processor: Specifications for the Interconnection of a Host and an IMP, Rept. 1822, Bolt Beranek and Newman, Inc. , Cambridge, Mass. ,
May 1978 revision , available from NTIS as AD A055996. This report is
revised periodically. New criteria and standards developed jointly by DCA, the
Military Services, and the Defense Agencies will be promulgated by the DCA.
All users are expected to meet ARPANET interface specifications.
15
ARPANET INFORMATION
FUNDING
The operation and maintenance (O&M) of the ARPANET backbone, i.e. , nodes,
interfaces, and internode communications circuits, is paid through the
Communications Services Industrial Fund (CSIF) which is managed and operated
by the Defense Communications Agency. The Defense Commercial Communications Office (DECCO) has responsibility for all leasing actions which take place under the CSIF. This function includes normal contract management
activities for the ARPANET. All bills for the CSIF portion of the ARPANET are paid by DECCO. Audits of contractors are performed by the Defense Contract Audit Agency (DCAA) at the request of DECCO. The vehicle used to request
communication services is the ARPANET TSR which is forwarded to DECCO
from DCA Code 535 as the ARPANET manager. Under the working capital or
revolving fund concept, predetermined subscriber rates are the basis for
recovering the cost of operating and maintaining the backbone network.
The estimated cost to operate and maintain the ARPANET backbone during a
fiscal year, divided by the estimated number of IMPs and TIPs in the network,
provides the annual cost per year per node:
Total O&M Cost
Annual Cost per IMP or TIP
# IMPs and # TIPs
All ARPANET customer activities will be billed monthly based on a
predetermined cost for each operational node in the backbone. The monthly
rate for FY78 is approx. $6000 and for FY79 and FY80 approx. $6500.
SECURITY
The ARPANET communications subnet or ' backbone' contains no security
features to insure privacy or the protection of classified defense information
transiting the network . Therefore, it is the responsibility of sponsors and those operating hosts on the network to take steps to protect information resident or
accessible through their host computers from access by unauthorized users,
and to provide protection against unauthorized access to classified information
which may reside or be accessible via their host computer link to the network .
There are no " login " procedures for initial network access. All access control is provided at the host level .
A secure subnet is possible by providing hosts with a Private Line Interface ( PLI) . The PLI has been approved by the National Security Agency ( NSA) and
costs approximately $ 55,000 per copy. The user also has to provide a KG 34 .
The PLI subnet can include up to 128 hosts constrained to 32 nodes.
16
ARPANET DIRECTORY ARPANET INFORMATION
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
COMPLAINTS
A complaint center teletype is maintained at the NCC for users reporting
problems or seeking assistance. Receiving and processing complaints is not
purely an NCC function, thus an additional channel for reporting unsatisfactory service has been developed. The ARPANET Unsatisfactory Service Report
(USR) has been established as the formal means of reporting deficiencies with respect to the operations of the ARPANET backbone communications.
Problems or complaints which cannot be resolved through normal channels
should be reported by means of the USR. The types of problems to be
included are, but are not limited to, the following:
. Excessive response time
. Inadequate restoral procedures
. Unsatisfactory maintenance support
The User (Sponsor) must determine when service has reached an unsatisfactory
point. The report may be sent over the ARPANET, AUTODIN, or by U.S. Mail .
Reports should be addressed to DCA Code 535 with information copies to the
NCC at BBN and any other activity as deemed appropriate by the originators.
(See CONTACTS section for addresses. )
USING RESOURCES ON THE ARPANET
Although the Resource Handbook describes resources available for use on the
ARPANET, mention of a resource in the Handbook in no way guarantees user
access. Access Access toto all almost any resource, other than the network itself, is under
the control of the host on which the resource resides. In all cases it is
assumed that any resource described is available only to authorized users who have valid accounts on the host at which they wish to use a given resource.
Accounts should be negotiated with the ACCOUNTS contact or with the
LIAISON . (See PERSONNEL under any given host entry )
The ARPANET is intended to be used solely for the conduct of, or in support
of, official U. S. Government business.
The use of the ARPANET must not be in violation of information privacy laws
and is not intended to compete with existing commercial services.

ARPANET DIRECTORY GENERAL CONTACTS

GENERAL CONTACTS
TIP PHONE NUMBERS
The NIC does not provide TIP phone numbers to network users. Access to a
TIP is at the discretion of the Sponsor for a given TIP, and is not guaranteed.
To obtain a TIP phone number, contact the Liaison for the TIP to be accessed.
( See the HOST ACRONYMS section for a list of TIPs, their corresponding
Liaison, and their geographical location . )

ARPANET DIRECTORY COMPUTERS BY HOST
NIC 47000 Oct. 1979
COMPUTER CONFIGURATIONS
EXPLANATION
This table is divided into two parts. The first part is organized by Host Name Acronyms and the second by Host Address. (For a definition of host name acronyms, see the HOST ACRONYMS table. )
For each host listed there is a description of the computer configuration for that host. The first computer
mentioned in this description is attached to the IMP and is by definition the ' host' computer. Other
computers are attached to the host computer as indicated by the arrows.
Text enclosed in parentheses () after the name of a computer describes the operating system in use on that
computer.
Type designations are:
S = Server host
U = User host
T TIP
VDH Very distant host
NOTE: The configuration of machines on the ARPANET changes often , so this table undoubtedly contains
inaccuracies. Send corrections or additions to FEINLER@SRI - KL.
295
|

ARPANET DIRECTORY INTRODUCTION
NIC 48000 Nov. 1980
BRIEF EXPLANATION OF THIS DIRECTORY
ATTENTION
The ARPANET Directory is the property of the Department of Defense. It is to
be used solely for the conduct of, or in support of, official U.S. government
business. The use of this book or its data base for advertising, mail distribution
lists , or for any other unauthorized purpose is strictly prohibited.
NIC INFORMATION
Services and documents available from the Network Information Center ( NIC) are described in this section of the Directory.
ARPANET INFORMATION
General information , useful definitions , policies, and procedures for using the
ARPANET are included in this section .
CONTACTS
This section lists contacts for obtaining general network information. It also lists
the ARPANET Sponsors and the ARPANET Liaison. ( For a definition of the
function of each of these groups see the section on ARPANET Information . )
INDIVIDUALS
Individuals who are authorized ARPANET users and who have supplied the
proper information to the ARPANET Network Information Center are listed alphabetically by last name in the INDIVIDUALS section of the directory. The
format is :
INDIVIDUAL'S NAME NIC IDENT
HARDCOPY - MAIL - ADDRESS
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS
PHONE NUMBER
HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION IDENT
where
NIC IDENT = a unique code ( usually one's initials) by which the NIC
Identification System recognizes and locates an individual .
NETWORK - MAIL - ADDRESS is in the form: USER - NAME@HOST - NAME. The
HOST NAME portion identifies a computer ( host) attached to the ARPANET at
which the individual receives delivery of his network mail . The USER NAME
portion of the network mail address is the character sequence by which that
host identifies the user's incoming mail .
HOST NAME S or ORGANIZATION IDENT the official identification code for the
host with which an individual is associated ; or if no ARPANET host exists, an
identification code representing the organization with which the individual is associated .
1
INTRODUCTION
NETWORK MAILBOX INDEX
This index is organized alphabetically by network mailbox along with the corresponding individual's name. It is a subset of the INDIVIDUALS listing and indicates what individuals are associated with which mailboxes. It is useful for
identifying users of group mailboxes.
HOSTS AND ASSOCIATES
Hosts are computers connected to the ARPANET. There are three kinds of hosts: SERVERS, USERs and TIPS. SERVER hosts have implemented SERVER
TELNET and are capable of providing services to remote users across the
network. USER hosts let their users access resources elsewhere on the network,
but do not provide services to non - local users and have not implemented SERVER TELNET. TIPs are special - case interface message processors ( IMFs)
which have one port dedicated to terminal connections. Associates are
network - related organizations that do not have hosts connected to the ARPANET. Hosts and associates are listed alphabetically by host acronym in the
format:
OFFICIAL HOST NAME ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
or by associate acronym in the format:
ASSOCIATE ACRONYM ORGANIZATION NAME
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
and by organization name in the format:
ORGANIZATION NAME OFFICIAL HOST NAME or ORGANIZATION
ACRONYM
ORGANIZATION ADDRESS
where
OFFICIAL HOST NAME = a unique acronym, obtained through negotiation with
the NIC, by which a host is known on the ARPANET.
ASSOCIATE IDENT = an identification acronym for associate organizations,
assigned by the NIC or by the sponsoring organization.
HOST NUMBER/IMP NUMBER ASSIGNMENTS
The Host No./IMP No. Table specifies which hosts are attached to each IMP or
TIP.
COMPUTERS
The Computer Tables indicate what computers are in use on the ARPANET. The
three separate tables are organized by host name , host address, and computer
manufacturer.
2
ARPANET DIRECTORY NIC INFORMATION
NIC 48000 Nov. 1980
NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER SERVICES
WHAT THE NETWORK INFORMATION CENTER ( NIC) DOES
The NIC serves as a center for collection and dissemination of information about the ARPANET. It is located at SRI International in Menlo Park, California . The
NIC was begun in 1970 as a research project to develop a prototypical network
information center, and up until July 1 , 1975 was sponsored by the Defense
Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) . Currently it is funded by the
Defense Communications Agency (DCA) to provide the services and publications
outlined below.
PUBLICATIONS
The Network Information Center publishes the following documents:
The ARPANET Directory A directory of users and hosts on the ARPANET. It
gives the names, online and U.S. mail addresses, phone number, and host
affiliation of ARPANET users, as well as useful ARPANET contacts and summary
tables of host information .
The ARPANET Protocol Handbook - A collection of the currently accepted ARPANET, Internet, and DoD network protocols.
The ARPANET Resource Handbook
on the ARPANET.
a compendium of the resources available
ARPANET News A newsletter distributed online by the NIC on behalf of DCA
to Liaison , Sponsors, and other interested people. The ARPANET News is primarily concerned with official announcements and with policies or changes
affecting the ARPANET. It also contains items of general network interest.
NOTE: ARPANET users who wish to receive the ARPANET News online should
send a message to NIC@SRI - KL asking to be put on the distribution list . The ARPANET News is not published in hardcopy.
ONLINE REFERENCE FILES
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET HOST NAMES LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL (host address = 1/2 dec . ) as
<NETINFO>HOSTS.TXT
This file contains the official list of host names and host addresses for hosts
attached to the ARPANET. It consists of host name, host address, type of
host ( i.e. , USER, SERVER, or TIP) and host nickname, if any. It is accessible to any network user via FTP using USERNAME ' anonymous' and PASSWORD
' guest' . It is mainly used to update local host name recognition tables.
3
NIC INFORMATION
THE OFFICIAL ARPANET LIAISON LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 1/2 dec . ) as <NETINFO >LIAISON.TXT
This file contains name, U. S. mail address, network mail address, phone, and
host affiliation for each network Liaison . It also lists the sponsoring agency
for each host . This file may be FTPed from the directory <NETINFO> to a
local ARPANET host using USERNAME ' anonymous' and PASSWORD ' guest' .
THE LIAISON NETWORK MAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST
An ASCII sequential file available from SRI - KL ( 1/2 dec . ) as
<NETINFO>LIAISON - SNDMSG.TXT
This file contains network mail addresses for all Network Liaison formatted for
online group distribution of messages via most mail programs. This file may
be FTPed from the directory <NETINFO> to a local ARPANET host using
USERNAME ' anonymous' and PASSWORD ' guest' .
REQUEST FOR COMMENTS ( RFCs)
ARPANET technical notes, known as Requests for Comments or RFCs, are
available online in the directory <NETINFO> at SRI - KL ( 1/2 dec. ) . They are
issued by the Coordinator of the Internet Working Group ( IWG) , currently Jon
Postel , and are announced via an online distribution list . Individuals wishing to
be added to the RFC distribution list should contact NIC@SRI - KL. Each RFC
remains online at the NIC for at least 21 days to give users a chance to
obtain copies . RFCs may be FTPed from the directory <NETINFO> to a local ARPANET host using USERNAME ' anonymous ' and PASSWORD ' guest' .
INTERNET EXPERIMENT NOTES ( IENS)
Internet Working Group technical notes, known as Internet Experiment Notes or
IENs, are kept online in directory < NETINFO> at SRI - KL ( host address , 1/2 ) ,
and Jon Postel issues these also. Individuals wishing to be added to the IEN
notification list should contact NIC@SRI - KL. Each IEN remains online at the
NIC for at least 21 days to give users a chance to obtain copies. IENs may also be FTPed from the directory <NETINFO> to a local ARPANET host using
USERNAME ' anonymous ' and PASSWORD ' guest' .
NIC / QUERY
Most of the information contained in the ARPANET Resource Handbook is also
maintained online as tree - structured files in the directory < NETINFO> at
SRI - KL ( 1/2 dec. ) . This information may be viewed through the NIC/ QUERY program. The query program is designed for novice or casual users and is
available to all ARPANET users. ( See ACCESS TO NIC / QUERY below. )
ACCESS TO NIC / QUERY
To access NIC /QUERY, connect to SRI - KL ( 1/2 dec . ) and type:
[ @] nic <CR>
then follow the instructions that are printed out .
4
ARPANET DIRECTORY NIC INFORMATION
NIC 48000 Nov. 1980
NOTE: Users may use this account for viewing reference files in the
NIC/QUERY system only. They may not use it to access other programs, and
it cannot be used for linking or loading the FTP program.
WHOIS
The NIC has implemented an experimental ARPANET ' white - pages' server,
called WHOIS, that makes fast query / response transactions over the network
to provide identification of network users ( name, U.S. mail address, network
mailbox, phone, and host affiliation ) . To add your name to this data base,
send your full name, U.S. mail address ( i.e. , your business address without abbreviations or acronyms) , network mailbox, telephone, and network sponsor
to NIC@SRI - KL.
ACCESS TO WHOIS
To access WHOIS, login to a host on which WHOIS resides ( see below) , then
type
whois LASTNAME <SP><CR>
To get help, type:
whois ? <CR>
The WHOIS program is currently running on hosts USC - ISI , USC - ISIB,
USC - ISIE, USC - ISIF, RADC - TOPS20, SRI - KL, SRI - KA, OFFICE - 1 , OFFICE -2,
and OFFICE - 3. It will be running on more ARPANET computers soon.
Contact NIC@SRI - KL for information .
HARDCOPY DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION
The NIC maintains files of many hardcopy documents pertaining to the ARPANET. Although the NIC ( since 1974) does not officially distribute hardcopy
reprints to network users, it will attempt to honor Interlibrary Loan requests for
items in the NIC collection that are not available in the open literature. This
service is provided to the extent that funds and staff permit and is not
guaranteed.
CORRESPONDING WITH THE NIC
Users are encouraged to correspond with the NIC concerning information
matters. If there is no entry in the Directory for you , or if the entry is incorrect or should be removed , please let us know. Suggestions from users are welcome
and will be considered within the constraints of a limited staff and budget.
To correspond with the NIC, use any one of the following methods of contact:
via network mail to
via U. S. mail to
NIC@SRI - KL
Elizabeth Feinler, Manager
ARPANET Network Information Center
Room J2021
SRI International
Menlo Park, California 94025
(415) 859-3695
334463
via phone to
via Telex to
